PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows -
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Braithwaite,Mr Cadman,Mrs Darling,Mr Hawker,Mr Milton and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to stop the commercial exploitation of the kangaroo.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House re-apply the ban on the export of kangaroo products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr John Brown and Mrs Darling.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth their concern regarding the proposed reduction in per capita grants to non- government schools in 1984 in conformity with the Commonwealth Government Guidelines for 1984 to be enacted within the State Grants (Schools) Act to be presented to Parliament later in 1983. Your petitioners express their deep concern about these arbitrary and discriminatory changes to Commonwealth Government funding of the educational rights of children in Australia and therefore respectfully request that:-

(1) funding to all non-government schools be maintained at at least the levels in real terms per student as were in existence at the commencement of the 1983 academic year pending a full review of the Guidelines by the Commonwealth Schools Commission, and

(2) that such review by the Commonwealth Schools Commission include consultation with representatives of the parents of students attending non- government schools, such representation to fairly represent the contribution made by the non-government schools to the overall education system in Australia.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of certain electors of Australia, Division of Dawson, shows-
that Australia is basically a Christian nation-as shown by figures from the last census.
that the Queen of Australia is recognised as head of Australia's Parliamentary System.

that no mandate has been sought from or given by the Australian people to alter our Oath of Allegiance, the proposal to amend the Citizenship Act not being publicised prior to the last Federal election.
that removal of references to God and the Queen is the first small significant step towards Republicanism.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government does not remove references to God and the Queen from our Oath of Allegiance and that it be allowed to remain unchanged.

PETITION.TITLE: Aircraft Noise at Launceston, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
Whereas the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation has sat in Launceston, Tasmania, and taken evidence on the problem of aircraft noise over that city, and
Whereas that evidence has established that a prima facie case does exist on the matter of encroaching aircraft noise on the lives of people living under the existing takeoff flight paths;
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
Request the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation to bring down an interim report on the matter of aircraft noise at Launceston, Tasmania as a matter of urgency, as;

(a) The situation is becoming worse and, with the expected introduction of a Boeing 727 on the night freight services, the position will become intolerable for those living under the northerly takeoff flight path.
(b) There will be more jet aircraft flights at night than experienced in the day.
(c) That the present measures planned by the Department of Aviation to alleviate the noise are totally inadequate and fail to recognise the basic causes of the problem.

(d) The increasing noise problem affects the well being of the patients in five major hospitals, the aged in five aged home complexes and children in fourteen major schools and colleges, all under the mandatory flight path as laid down by the Department of Aviation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-west region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.

2. Note that such a proposal will result in the destruction of the historic village of Pitt Town, Longneck wildlife reserve, significant aboriginal relics and the historic Scheyville camp and will irreversibly alter the character of the five Macquarie towns.
3. Consider the resulting intolerable pollution of the Hawkesbury river.
4. Note that approximately 2000 properties will be resumed, displacing over 5000 residents.

5. Consider the detrimental effects of noise, air and vehicular pollution on many thousands of residents in the surrounding districts of Hawkesbury, Baulkham Hills, Hornsby Shires, Blacktown and Penrith cities.
6. Give immediate consideration to finding a more suitable alternative site.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
We have become the innocent victims of your Government's Medicare scheme.
We are forced to pay 1 per cent of our wages only to receive less per capita benefits than the people of other States.

Without canvassing the rights or wrongs of the dispute between the Federal Government and the State of Queensland the fact is that because of it over one million Queenslanders, who contribute to health funds, are being blatantly discriminated against compared with people in the rest of Australia.
Because of the dispute over the introduction of Medicare, Queensland public hospital bed charges are $120 per day compared with $80.00 per day in the other states. This is grossly unfair.
As it was the Federal Government which decided to introduce Medicare, we believe it is their responsibility to take action allowing health funds' rates in Queensland to be kept at reasonable levels.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives assembled, should-
Use its influence with Government so as to avoid the discrimination (of $40 per day) against insured Queenslanders.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, parents and teachers working for and in the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia, respectfully showeth that:
We support the Federal Government's determination to restore the community's confidence in public education.

We support the Federal Government's opposition to base grants to all non government schools (a) by reducing funds to those schools already operating above community standards and (b) funding other schools according to need.
We support the Federal Government's policy of negotiations and planning with State/Territory Governments regarding joint programs for improvements in Government schools in the next decade.
1. We ask that the Federal Government increase recurrent funding for Government schools as promised.
2. We ask that the Federal Government provide promised funding for special programs to assist primary children with learning difficulties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that:
(a) Too much Government Aid is given to serve Australia's Foreign Policy interests rather than to help the poor.
(b) The needs and wishes of the poor are often ignored when projects are being selected and implemented.
(c) Projects are often selected and designed to suit what Australia can provide rather than what the poor really need.
(d) Technical imputs and expertise are emphasised at the expenses of social factors.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government should:

(1) Reorient its aid program so that its principal aim is to eliminate chronic proverty in our region. (2) Choose recipient countries systematically on the basis of (a) Need of the people; (b) Likelihood of aid reaching the poorest and (c) Australia's Historical links and geographical position.
(3) Choose types of aid systematically on the basis of whether the Recipient government has the commitment and ability to help the poorest in that country.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm;
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programs;
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices;
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals;
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting and Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That because television and radio
(a) affect our social and moral environment;
(b) are family media watched and heard by many children at all times, and
(c) present too much explicit violence and sex,
they therefore need stronger control than other media and the existing standards need stricter enforcement in both national A.B.C., and commercial sectors.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Australian Government will amend the Broadcasting and Television Act, in relation to both national and commercial broadcasters, to legislate
(a) for adequate and comprehensive programs in the best interests of the general public;
(b) for a ''Dual System of Regulation'' enforced by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal by internal regulation and external control;
(c) for an independent consumer body to represent the best interests of the general public; and
(d) for immediate and effective penalties to be imposed for breaches of program and advertising standards.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Omega Base
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. Omega by sending low frequency signals, penetrating sea water enables hunter -killer submarines to establish their position and to launch a ''first strike'' attack. Omega is also used by AWACs, the flying radar stations, and for other military purposes.
2. Omega is an important U.S. military base and a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Omega would have a disastrous effect on Victoria and Melbourne .
3. Omega and other U.S. bases in Australia endanger, rather than protect us. They add a new unnecessary menace to a nuclear arms race that must be stopped, if we are to survive.
Your petitioners pray that members and the House assembled will close Omega.

Debate resumed from 6 March, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Drummond Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate I wish to concentrate my remarks on the Fresh Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1984. The ultimate purpose of this Bill and its related measures is the recoupment of expenses incurred in the inspection for export of fresh fruit and vegetables. On the face of it, in principle the recovery of 50 per cent of costs has much to recommend it. No government service is ultimately free as costs eventually have to be met by the taxpayer. The users of a service should, where practicable, make a contribution. On the other hand, some industries feel that it is fair for the Government to meet inspection charges in lieu of providing other support.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the principle of the Bill is not in dispute. What I do dispute very strongly is the intention of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), as stated in this place last week, to bring these charges into effect on 1 April. Such a move will have the most adverse consequences for the export vegetable and fruit growers of Australia and more particularly the growers of Western Australia, the majority of whom I represent as the member for Forrest.

I make it clear to the House and the Government that increasingly it is the fruit and vegetable growers of Western Australia who are most directly concerned with the export markets for fresh fruit and vegetables. The markets in other States are basically concerned with domestic consumption. Even Tasmania, which is far more renowned as a fruit growing State, is increasingly concentrating on export to the north island of Australia. Western Australia, however, looks to expand markets in Asia, for obvious geographical reasons. For this reason I hope that the Minister and the Parliament will understand why the protests from Western Australian growers are much louder than those from other parts of Australia.

By exporting high quality fruit and vegetables, growers are not only earning this country foreign exchange but also are relieving pressure on the domestic fruit and vegetable markets. It would be in nobody's interest to see growers leave the export market because of the new cost burden. Many of the export operators are operating at marginal levels now. The effect of this proposed and ill-timed cost imposition will be highly adverse. Firstly, a new cost will be added in the midst of the export season, particularly with regard to apples and pears. Growers were anticipating an effective cost rise per case of 11.38c, quite apart from the accounting, administrative and clerical costs that will follow. All too often governments forget that new taxes and charges impose hidden paperwork costs on the primary producers and small business. This is another example.

The second factor making 1 April an inappropriate date for fruit exporters in particular is that the revision of export standard regulations with revised grade standards is not yet completed. Clearly, this would add to the difficulties faced by the growers. Early in February the executive of the Western Australian Fruit Growers Association (Inc) requested of the Minister that the new charges be deferred until revised grade standards became effective. The growers suggested 1 December as the date for introduction, which I support as it will enable the charges to be phased in at the commencement of a new season. It is significant that the growers have been supported both by the Western Australian Fruit Shippers Committee and the Western Australian Vegetable Exporters Association, underscoring the concern felt by all facets of the local fruit and vegetable industries. Until the revised export standards are finalised , growers will not be in a position to decide whether they can afford export inspection and at what level.

The amount and cost of overtime by inspectors at the height of the season does not seem to have been taken into account. The vegetable exporters of my State have said that they believe that the proposed charges are greatly in excess of the costs involved. Currently fruit growers have been told that the consignment forms to be used in conjunction with inspection charge procedures are unsatisfactory and have to be redesigned in consultation with the export representatives who have to use them. Once again, the House will note just how unsuitable this 1 April target date is.

The day before this legislation was introduced into this House the Minister replied to the Western Australian Fruit Growers Association, simply stating his intention to proceed, but mentioned also that an interim inspection policy council will be working to keep costs to a minimum. He did not answer its lengthy telex in any detail. I imagine that he will respond to that and to speeches by other members on this side of the House in this debate and that the reasons for his proceeding with this date, if that is his intention, will be made clear to all of us after my well-reasoned speech.

In itself, such an announcement is welcome but it would seem more sensible to wait until the council meets and makes recommendations before actually beginning collection of charges. But at least the Fruit Growers Association received a reply from the Minister. As of 1 March, after the introduction of the Bill, the Western Australian Fruit and Vegetable Exporters Association had received no acknowledgment of its telex from the Minister. That does not say much for this Government's willingness to listen to the views of our primary industries.

The Minister noted in the speech that payment will not be due until the end of May, but I still maintain that the growers and exporters have been given insufficient time to adapt to this new system. The cost to Western Australian fruitgrowers last year was estimated at approximately $l30,000. The cost to the little area of Donnybrook, which is a major exporter of apples, was something like $50,000. That is a lot to be taken out of one small district.

It has been strongly suggested that the proposed charges have been reached by averaging the true costs of Western Australian fruit and vegetable exporters against those of less efficient and smaller volume sectors of the industries on a national basis. This underscores the burden that has been foisted on Western Australian export growers. With the administrative confusion and costs added to the direct charges, we have to ask whether the Government is serious about the encouragement of fruit and vegetable exporters. I point out that in some competing countries inspection charges are paid in full by the Government. The horticultural exporters of my State do not receive much government support compared with that received by many overseas countries. Discontinuation of the export expansion grants has not assisted the industries facing overseas competition; this should be considered in the context of the new charges.

The Government ought to realise that horticultural exporters are hampered by the effects of payroll tax, customs, import duty on production equipment, sales tax on packaging, materials and the like. TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I would like to thank the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Gear) for his sympathetic notice of motion earlier this morning and point out to the House that the husky voice I currently have as a result of a temporary ailment is the only resemblance I bear to the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party. The Fresh Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Bill and the Bills being debated cognately deal with the recoupment of 50 per cent of export inspection charges. This policy has been recommended both by the former and present governments. In fact such a policy was introduced in the dried fruit industry from May 1981 and this Thirty-third Parliament was responsible for the introduction of such a policy in the livestock, grains, edible oils and egg industries.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that we have chosen, by mutual agreement, to deal with these Bills in a cognate debate. Whilst I accept the wisdom of that I am a little unhappy because they are in fact related but not similar Bills. The honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) pointed out the inconsistency of dealing with fruit and vegetables together as if the crops had no difference, and, of course, the dried fruit levy is unrelated to the export inspection charge. So I have chosen to address the House in two parts. The first of my comments is directed at the export inspection charge and the second at the dried fruits levy.

As I have indicated, there has been general acceptance of the concept of a 50 per cent export inspection charge. The industry has largely accepted this, although it has been anxious to point out that in many cases this is not the most opportune time to introduce this additional charge. I know, as the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) will say and as many have interjected, that it is never the most opportune time to introduce any sort of additional charge on industry. Charges on industries are rather like parliamentary salaries. When they are introduced they are never well received. But I put it to the House that in the case of the apple and pear industries and the canned fruit industries this timing is most inopportune. Both of these industries are halfway through a processing year. In fact, both are in the process of introducing new grade standards and both are for those reasons seeking deferment. These industries are seeking, not the abolition of the charge but a deferment of the charge pending their internal restructure. Both of these industries, as the Minister is well aware, are in a process of delicate restructure.
I will quote from page 2473 of Hansard of 14 May 1981. On that occasion the following statement was made about the introduction of the export inspection charge into the dried vine fruit industry:

Essentially, dried vine fruit growers are price takers and not farmers who can influence the world market. It is very much a market in which there is a lot of competition. Export prices at the moment are slightly higher than in previous years due to major crop failures . . .
Then the speaker went on to say:

Because, as I have said, Australian DVF producers are essentially price takers on world markets-about 60 per cent of Australian production is exported-any increase in charges will affect the industry's ability to compete.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—I will tell the honourable member who said it in just a moment. A little later the speaker went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I will return to the basic point: Why begin this policy of cost recovery for inspection services as a revenue raiser in one of the weakest rural industries? The industry has a lot of problems.

The honourable member for Darling Downs asked who said that. The person who made the statement was the present Minister for Primary Industry. All we are asking is that the honourable member for Werriwa, who in opposition made that statement about the dried vine fruit industry, now consider a similar sympathetic attitude to the industries presently being considered by the House. I reiterate that significantly the industries are not objecting but what they are seeking is a liaison with the Minister-if honourable members will pardon the term-and an element of consensus from him to allow them to adjust this figure and to introduce this export charge so that it does not adversely affect industries which are in a very perilous situation.

I suggest that these charges, small though they are in the total costs that these industries face, could well be, in the case of industries as finely balanced as the apple, pear and canned fruit industry, the straw that breaks the camel's back. The plea is for the Minister to consider in some way phasing in these charges and liaising with the industry to minimise this impost. The great concern that I have found faced by the canned fruit industry is that the inspection charge could result in duplicity, in being forced to inspect twice canned fruit for export. Of course, that is an absurdity, because once the fruit is in a can it cannot be seen or inspected. The significant inspection occurs on the line before the fruit runs into the can. The domestic market in Australian canned fruit demands a minimum standard which would meet export requirements. The industry is saying to the Minister: 'Surely we could minimise our costs if we were able to look again at the way in which we go about our export inspection '. These are the sentiments being echoed by all of the other industries. They are saying: 'Allow us to assess the way in which we carry out the export inspection and to introduce a system which will involve the minimum necessary inspection in order to maintain the maximum standards'.

I suggested earlier that it was inappropriate for canned fruit and vegetables to be considered together. It is also inappropriate for canned and frozen fruit to be considered together. The canned fruit industry is still an export oriented industry. The frozen fruit industry is a domestic oriented industry. The frozen fruit industry principally occupies the Australian market. The honourable member for Darling Downs, in his speech to this House, said that industries are calling for greater flexibility from government in the introduction of these export inspection charges.

I turn now to the citrus industry. The citrus industry, in harmony with the other industries that I have brought to the House's attention this morning, also does not dispute the introduction of this export inspection charge. The citrus industry is concerned, as are the other industries, about the form this inspection takes. The citrus industry is seeking some flexibility in the introduction of this charge. The citrus industry faces a charge of $10 per consignment or 9c per package. In my conversation with industry representatives, they have been concerned about whether this form of charge will penalise small consignments. They have been concerned about whether the charge is to be paid if notice of intent to export is lodged and the produce is not subsequently shipped . They have been concerned about what happens when we export to countries which do not require government inspection or phytosanitary certificates. They are concerned about the impact of this sort of legislation on fruit juices where the standard of the fruit juice in the container is largely a matter of adhering to labelling requirements rather than any other form of minimum standard.

I point out to the House that the former Minister for Primary Industry, the former member for Gippsland, Mr Nixon, gave an assurance on 15 October 1982 that it was the previous Government's intention to sort out the inspection technique first and then to levy the industry for 50 per cent of the charges. The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), as Acting Minister for Primary Industry, made a plea to the industry to have an opportunity for self-regulation and for the industry to have some control on the form of export inspection that was to be levied against it.

I turn now to the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill. As was said by previous speakers, the intention of this Bill is to increase the maximum permissible levy that can be charged dried fruit growers per tonne of dried fruit. I would not suggest that dried fruit growers welcome the increase in this levy. However, I put it to honourable members that they recognise that it is unavoidable. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), in a speech that had little, if anything, to do with export inspection and a great deal to do with what he saw as the fine physique that he possesses, made comment about the need for promotion of the dried vine fruit industry. We accept that, but the dried vine fruit industry is not an industry without problems. Indeed, the dried vine fruit industry's major markets are overseas markets. Dried fruits in Australia, vine fruits and stone fruits, are one of the unique Australian industries. It needs to be appreciated that while we sit in the comfort of this House, people are slaving in 38 degree or 40 degree temperatures in order to produce dried vine fruits for Australia. People have done this over the Christmas break and have delivered dried tree fruits.

Most of the dried vine fruit growers will receive little more for the price of a tonne of fruit delivered after they have gone to the trouble of drying that fruit, than they would have received had they simply delivered that fruit fresh to a winery or processor. They are bound to dry the fruit because the wine industry has been so decimated by the Government's decision to introduce an impost on fortified wine that there are surpluses and dried vine fruit outlets are the only direction that they can turn. It has put them on the rack. They have to decide whether to dry them or leave them on the vines. That uncomfortable choice is being faced by growers who are now working for nothing because they could have received just as much had they chosen the easier outlet by delivering those grapes to a winery.

I make that point because this levy will allow the dried vine fruit industry and the dried fruit industry generally to pursue additional market outlets and additional productivity gains through the research that is available to them. The dried vine fruit and dried tree fruit producers in harmony with all other primary producers in Australia face the dilemma of rising costs and have been forced to meet the rising costs by rising productivity. It would be as well for this nation if other sectors also faced a similar technique for meeting their rising costs. Only rising productivity can keep the dried fruit industry from bankruptcy. Research is the survival kit for the dried fruit industry. Promotion is a part of that survival kit. We have already seen, in the industry, what research can do. The introduction, for example, of the Ramsay rootstock has meant that sultana vines in the Riverland and Sunraysia areas have had dramatic increases in production because that rootstock has proved to be both salt and nematode tolerant. Research is the one key that has allowed these increases in production to occur.

I suggest to the Government that the preparedness of growers to accept this additional levy indicates that they are prepared to take their share of the burden in making the industry even more competitive and cost efficient than it is. They seek from the Government a similar preparedness to control wages, on- costs and inflation so that, as a nation, we will remain competitive. They seek a government prepared to act responsibly and accountably in economic management. We see little evidence of that when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tells us in this House, as he did yesterday, that estimates of the deficit are purely illusory and meaningless. If he is prepared to be as shortsighted as that about economic management the growers are apprehensive about what the future will hold for them in the control and management of inflation and wage costs.

The other Bill before the House is the Apple and Pear Levy Amendment Bill. The honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher) has already spoken at length on this Bill. It is significant that apples and pears currently destined for distillation are meeting a levy at the processing rate. What has surprised me, as I investigated this Bill, has been the preparedness of apple and pear growers to accept their share of increased levies and to point out to me the amount of money they, as growers, already generate through various levies in order to be involved in research and promotion in the industry.

In South Australia the present levy on apples and pears on average is 9c a bushel and costs the average grower $45 per acre per year. In addition he faces a State levy of $12 per acre per year or a total outlay of $57 per acre per year , which is a vote of confidence in the industry expressed by the apple and pear growers in order to ensure their future survival in the Australian economy. Like the dried fruit industry, the apple and pear industry has to export into a highly competitive market. In order to remain viable it must maintain its productivity. The amendment we are considering exempts apples and pears for processing from the full levy rate and allows fruit for distillation to be levied at the juicing rate. I believe there is unanimous support in the House for that amendment. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I was disappointed with the contribution of the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck). As he says well over three quarters of the apple industry of Tasmania is in his electorate. I know there were problems with that and with the industry, and the industry then picked up for two years. But it is in terrible trouble. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) and I did work very hard, through the Victorian Government, to make sure that all avenues of rural reconstruction were made available to growers who had some hope of viability. The point that worries me is one reflected by the industry itself. I refer to imports. I am certainly sympathetic towards producers' concerns about imports of subsidised Greek fruit. The week after next there will be two days of talks in Canberra between EC and Australian officials and Ministers, and I assure the honourable member for Mallee that the issues relating to dried fruits will be discussed with a view to achieving a better marketing climate and an understanding of each other's position.

When I introduced these Bills I pointed out that the legislation to impose the 50 per cent recoupment charge on honey inspection was introduced by the previous Government in March 1982. This clearly shows the hypocrisy of the Opposition. This measure was introduced in March 1982, and the Senate then referred the relevant Bills to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. Apparently if the Opposition has its way in the Senate the legislation will again go through that Senate committee. It has already been through that Committee once and we took that into account when framing these Bills. As we all know, the Liberal-National Party Government introduced charges for inspection in 1979. It introduced charges for the inspection of meat, wool and grains and the policy of that Government was to extend the cost recovery to all export products. Honey was another such product, and in March 1982 this measure was proposed. Admittedly it was referred to a Senate committee, but that Government did introduce the charge.

When I took over my portfolio it was obvious that the Department of Primary Industry, acting under instructions from the previous Government and Minister, had all these matters in train and was subjecting the various industries to a thorough costing so that inspection which had just gone on willy-nilly before, with no scrutiny and no attention by the industries themselves, would not continue in that fashion. Industries were not really required to look at the level of costs or the systems of inspection. For the first time they were placed on notice and had to take into account just how much of this inspection was needed. Before they were getting the service for nothing and so did not have to focus on it. All I can say is that the present Government agrees with that policy of the user pays. After all, the taxpayer is still subsidising the services to the extent of 50 per cent. It was the then Government that initiated these charges, not the present Government.

This Government is committed to making the inspection services as efficient and cost effective as possible and as this is progressively done any cost savings will be passed on as lower charges. One simply cannot assume that we should never impose a charge or system of inspection which has to operate on a day to day basis. We cannot work on the principle that we should never do anything, strike any charge, because subsequently we might find a better way to carry out that practice. So any cost savings will be progressively passed on to the industry. There is an example of that, which some people seem to have missed, in the canned and frozen vegetables legislation. The review of practices currently under way has already enabled charges to be reduced to one-third of the levels anticipated only four months ago. So we are acting, but we do have a top rate inspection service.

To give industries a window and some idea of what is going on, we have set up the Interim Inspection Policy Council. The previous Government would not do that . It intended to impose these measures without any consultation. Our proposals give the industries exposure to the systems, to levels of inspection and to the costs. We are not inspecting for quality in any ambiguous sense. Where phytosanitary certificates are required, someone has to look at the product and issue such a certificate. We are looking at matters such as health standards and at product specifications and grade to make sure that no one, for example with apples, tops up the boxes. I am surprised that it has to be said again and again , but we now have an inspection service which is becoming more and more efficient and more and more set in place. The reason is that we are in competition with the rest of the world to sell our products. We cannot continue with some of these silly ideas of self-regulation when we are in such a highly competitive environment. If there are to be self-regulation measures, they have to be applied in some ordered, administered and regular fashion. We cannot just proceed down the path of not doing it properly.

A decent and proper export inspection service is a major selling point for our private traders when they go overseas. We must have an export inspection service that really does look at the quality and standard of our products. Surely we do not have to be reminded of the meat substitution scandal when the previous Government, and I suppose all previous governments, tried to do it on the cheap. That is the reason our enormous beef trade was put at risk. It was prejudiced by the previous Government because the previous Government tried to do it on the cheap and was not prepared to insist that a proper export inspection service be set up. I do not have to go into all that. We know all about it. This Government is carrying on the work of the previous Government. Once the previous Government realised that we had to have a proper export inspection service, it went for a user pays principle to the extent of 50 per cent. We are following down the same path and will carry on the same task.

The honourable member for Darling Downs has given notice that he will dump all these Bills on to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. Apparently he has the acquiescence of the Australian Democrats in the Senate on this matter. The honourable member helpfully gave to us the matters which the Committee would look at. The first one, as I recall, was: Is there any legal and international requirement for an inspection? Let us go through that.

The official importing country requirements vary depending on the products covered. In the fresh fruit and vegetable area, officially-issued phytosanitary, that is, plant health, inspection and certification is required as a condition of entry overseas for an estimated 80 per cent of our export products. In some cases, for example, the export of certain fruits to the North American market, these requirements involve inspection extending to the growing area. There is no need for a Senate committee to look at this. We actually know what goes on overseas and what the requirements are.

As I have already said, the Senate Committee on Finance and Government Operations in its May 1982 report reviewed the situation applying to honey, but apparently the honourable member for Darling Downs wants to send the matter back to that same Committee.

In the case of canned and processed fruits and vegetables there are few specific overseas requirements imposing an inspection obligation. Generally products have to meet fairly universal food law requirements that they be sound, free from adulteration and true-to-label.

It is important to realise that the purpose of inspection is broader than just ensuring overseas requirements are met. It aims also at maintaining Australia's image as a consistent producer of quality product, and at preventing that image and the trade of conscientious and reliable exporters being damaged by the actions of a few. Also, it is essential that our exports are of adequate quality and presentation to compete effectively overseas with those of our major competitors. On Asian fresh fruit markets, for example, our competitors include the United States of America, New Zealand and South Africa, whose products are generally well-controlled, through entrenched and sophisticated industry self- regulation, or strict government monitoring.

The second matter which the honourable member for Darling Downs wants the Senate Committee to look at is: How can industry be more self-regulatory? As I have already said, the currently-proceeding review of export inspection arrangements envisages, for canned and processed fruits and vegetables and honey , a completely new inspection approach-it is already in these Bills-involving quality assurance monitoring for the best firms allied to more objective inspection arrangements for the remainder. The quality assurance approach would apply to both areas. Firms with a good export performance record and established in-house quality control procedures will be able to enter into approved quality assurance arrangements with the inspection service. Under these the service will essentially rely on the firm's own quality control to ensure compliance with export requirements, with minimal monitoring. This is essentially a system of self-regulation backed up with the minimal control necessary to ensure products are up to standard. What it means is that exporters are given the opportunity to demonstrate objectively that they are capable of operating effectively in a self -regulatory manner. If honourable members look at the Bills they will see-this is particularly so with respect to honey-that there is a three-strand level of charging.

Quality assurance monitoring criteria will be designed to operate flexibly, to take into account differences in individual circumstances from firm to firm. The random sampling approach is envisaged for honey and parallels approaches being developed for the inspection of fish, dairy products, edible oils and eggs.

For canned and processed fruit and vegetable products, the review of arrangements outside the quality assurance area is not as advanced as it is for honey. The very large production runs make a random sampling approach more difficult to effectively implement. My Department is, however, looking at alternatives, aimed at achieving cost savings, which would rely to a greater extent on monitoring company control records and laboratory practice as part of the inspection approach.

In the fresh fruit and vegetable area, the phytosanitary inspection effort required to meet overseas requirements is by its nature relatively intensive. For this reason, although random monitoring already applies in many instances, there is a limit to which it can be cut back. In consultation with industry, inspection quality standards are currently being developed aimed at clarifying and harmonising export requirements and this work is being intermeshed with the development of domestic standards by the Australian United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association. A review of inspection procedures and arrangements followed by State departments, which carry out the inspection on the Commonwealth's behalf is also proceeding.

The next matter which the honourable member for Darling Downs raised was: Is the flag fall plus a per package charge justified: Why not an ad valorem charge? The so-called flag charge applies only to fresh fruit and vegetables. The size of export consignments of these products is highly variable. Many shipments consist of thousands of packages of such things as apples, oranges or onions. But there are also many small consignments of one or a few boxes, many of which use air freight. The cost of inspecting these small consignments is high, particularly when an inspector is called out to an airport to do just one small job. The charge is to recoup part of the cost of inspection. The flag fall charge reflects the fact that it costs more to inspect small consignments.

If there were no minimum charge large shippers would be subsidising the shippers of small consignments. If there were no minimum charge the charge per package would have to be increased from 9c to 12c to recoup 50 per cent of the total of inspection costs. Indeed, shippers of very small consignments might well escape payment altogether since it could cost more that it was worth to collect very small amounts from them.

An ad valorem charge is attractive in theory. In practice it would be very difficult to administer effectively since it would have to rely on shippers truthfully stating the value of their consignments. It would also have the unfair result that high value produce would be subsidising low value produce even though the actual inspection costs may be identical in both instances.

The next question which the honourable member raised was: Should the Industries Assistance Commission be asked to look at a quality assurance scheme? The approach to quality assurance inspection being developed by my Department is based on the Australian standard for suppliers quality control systems developed by the Standards Association of Australia, and on international work in the area . The concept has been extensively canvassed already with exporters in a number of product areas, including fish and dairy, and is currently being explored with the canned and processed fruit and vegetable industry. The quality assurance approach to inspection is designed to be flexible to meet different circumstances and approaches to quality control followed in different firms. It is designed as far as possible to tie in with established, effective, quality control systems rather than imposing new and different requirements on firms which already operate effective control. The system is, moreover, to be trailed extensively before it is formally introduced. In these circumstances it would be a waste of both resources and time to refer the matter for IAC inquiry.

A further matter which the honourable member for Darling Downs wants the Senate Committee to consider is: Are there too many inspectors? The aim of the export inspection review is to ensure the service is cost-effective and that inspection is limited to essential areas of control except where otherwise justified by the industry. A review of the relevance of current inspection staffing levels is part of this process, in consultation with both the unions and industry.

Importantly, the currently-proposed charging levels for canned and frozen fruits and honey reflect anticipated savings under the new inspection regime. The fresh fruit and vegetable review is not yet sufficiently advanced to anticipate likely savings. It would be anomalous, however, to exclude that area from charging at the current time when charges are to be introduced for the other export sectors.

The next question that the honourable member for Darling Downs maintains the Opposition will refer to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations is: Why is there not a difference between canned and frozen fruit and vegetable charges? The revised system proposed for these products is to inspect plants and their procedures, to register them and then to randomly monitor their continued compliance with requirements. This is exactly what the honourable member for Darling Downs proposed should be done. That is the system which the Government is applying to those products where such an approach is possible. The costs of running the system are unlikely to differ as between plants with comparable standards and performance irrespective of whether they produce canned or frozen products. Consequently a standard charge for both categories of product is considered appropriate. Experience may show that some individual establishments require a greater degree of monitoring than others. If that occurs, the Government will be looking to implement a differential charging system so that establishments which are more costly to supervise will pay more in charges. In other words, there will be an incentive for establishments to adopt satisfactory quality assurance procedures so as to avoid having to pay additional charges. (Extension of time granted)

The final question that the honourable member for Darling Downs maintains the Opposition will refer to the Senate Committee concerns the basis of State charges and accountability. Of the Bills under debate, this question relates only to those dealing with fresh fruit and vegetables. The States charge the Commonwealth for inspection of these products. They keep itemised accounts of the costs incurred, which are subject to audit by State Auditors-General. The accounts when so audited are submitted to my Department, accompanied by a certification given by the Chief Officer of the State Department concerned. In our federal system there are many areas of co-operative activity such as this. This system of accounting is common to many of the activities.

There were other comments about Portuguese armies of inspectors. I do not know how the Portuguese got into this but I think I have already addressed that issue because the review proposed an inspection approach which would be based predominantly on objective criteria, and these will be flagged clearly to both industry and inspection staff. The honourable member also said that the honey standards are still too high. I have already made mention of that inasmuch as we took fully into account the conclusions of the Senate committee that has already looked at it.

One of the final points that the honourable gentleman made is that the charging Bill for honey should await the report of the Industries Assistance Commission on the honey industry. In the case of honey, what we are looking at is a charge which is much less than one per cent of the freight on board value of a tonne of honey. The draft IAC report on the honey industry, which was released on 14 February 1984, did not make any comments on the question of charging for export inspection other than to mention the charging proposal in this legislation. The draft report did not recommend any assistance to the industry. As I have said, it is Government policy to recover 50 per cent of the cost of export inspection of primary produce. Should the IAC recommend in its final report that some form of assistance to the industry is justified, in accordance with normal procedures this will be considered by the Government. It is rather a weak crutch to put as rationale for delaying the passage of these Bills that because there is an IAC report into an industry relating to different questions one should not put through a package of Bills.

The only other point to which I wish to reply is that raised by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), who made a claim with respect to fresh and canned fruit and vegetables being an export industry on the one hand and a domestic industry on the other. The point here is that the plants which wish to export frozen produce, and some do, must comply with the same kinds of requirements as the export canneries and, of course, they then incur similar inspection costs for registration and monitoring.

I have taken some considerable time to answer the points of which the honourable member for Darling Downs so kindly gave notice in the debate last night. I am sure that the Australian Democrats will accept the explanation given and the fact that the Government has addressed itself to every one of these points. It is quite clear to me that the Opposition is simply focusing on the fact that people do not want to pay. The rest of the arguments are rather weak arguments indeed. Madam Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later hour.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Clause 28, page 18, lines 27-40, omit sub-clause (3), substitute the following sub-clause:
''(3) A person shall, for the purposes of this section, be taken to sexually harass another person if-

A person shall, for the purposes of this section, be taken to a sexually harass another person if-
(a) the first-mentioned person makes a sexual advance, or a request for sexual favours, to the other person, or engages in other unwelcome conduct of a sexual nature in relation to the other person;
(b) the other person takes reasonable steps to communicate to the first- mentioned person that the advance, request or conduct is unwelcome; and

(c) (i) the first-mentioned person makes it reasonably appear to the other person that a rejection of the advance, a refusal of the request or the taking objection to the conduct would disadvantage the other person in any way in connection with the other person's studies or the other person's application for admission to an educational institution as a student; or

(ii) as a result of the other person's rejection of the advance, refusal of the request or taking of objection to the conduct, the other person is disadvantaged in any way in connection with the other person's studies or the other person's application for admission to an educational institution as a student.''.

In moving these two amendments, the Opposition does not in any way want to dilute the provisions of the Bill. We are in fact supportive of the objectives of these two clauses. There was considerable debate in the Senate, however, about whether the endeavour of these clauses to correct discrimination against a person following complaints of sexual harassment actually jeopardised the position of the person who is alleged to have done the harassing and the discrimination. The Opposition is not fully satisfied with the answer given by the responsible Minister in the Senate. Perhaps the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) will be able to comment a little more fully on these concerns. Perhaps the most sensible way of starting the debate is actually to go to some of the reports of sexual harassment under State jurisdiction. Looking at page 11 of the 1983 annual report of the Commissioner for Equal Opportunity in Victoria one sees the following:

A fifth of all employment complaints this year alleged sexual harassment in the workplace. 41 complaints-a quarter of all employment complaints from women-dealt with various forms of such behaviour, ranging from persistent innuendo through unwelcome touching to sexual assault.

In earlier years, only one complaint had ever been received about sexual overtures made to a job applicant, but three such complaints were registered this year. In 20 of the 41 cases, the complaint was linked to the loss of employment-either dismissal following alleged advances, or resignation of the victim owing to pressure or distress. In 17 cases, the aggrieved woman complained that the unwanted behaviour created detrimental work conditions of fear, hostility or offensiveness; and in one case, a salary classification was felt to be contingent upon acceptance of sexual attentions. The outcomes of these sexual harassment complaints (including one complaint in accommodation against an estate agent) was as shown in Table 4.

Table 4 on page 12 in fact shows that nine complaints were withdrawn; eight were not substantiated; 19 were settled by conciliation; two were referred to the Board; and four were still under investigation. The settlements included: Formal apology; education of respondent to prevent harassment; payment of lost wages; damages for distress; transfer of the harasser; dismissal of the harasser; reprimand of the harasser; reinstatement of the complainant; and promotion of the complainant. I believe that that indicates a level and pattern of conduct which would be unacceptable to all persons in this House and, indeed, to all decent Australians.

The only reservation expressed by the Opposition is that in the pursuit of redress by people who believe they have been discriminated against in employment , on the basis that they rejected some sexual advance or made a complaint about unwelcomed attention of a sexual character, a vendetta may be pursued as a result of some falling out between people.The person who is unaware that that sexual attention is unwelcome or that if it was once welcome it has now ceased to be must not be unjustly treated. The object of these amendments is to ensure that the aggrieved person actually is obliged to communicate the nature of the complaint to the offending person who, it is said sometime later, was discriminated on the grounds of the complaint about sexual harassment. As I have said this matter was dealt with at length in the Senate, and I understand the intention. Again one sees in the report of the New South Wales Anti- Discrimination Board other cases of sexual harassment which are really quite horrifying. The Board spends quite some time in its report examining the famous case of O'Callaghan v. Loder and the Commissioner for Main Roads. That case is mentioned in the report of the New South Wales Board of 30 June 1983, from which I have quoted earlier in the debate. It is educational to note that the report states:

The women complaining of sexual harassment in these work situations are typically young and poorly educated. They are almost always not a member of a union and, in addition to sexual harassment, are exploited in their rates of pay and working hours. They complain that their employers treat them as if they ' owned' them. They also complain of verbal abuse, physical touching and grabbing, and repeated and sometimes violent requests for sexual relations which, they are told, it is part of their job to provide.
The report continues:

As youth unemployment increases, particularly amongst young women, this type of sexual harassment becomes more difficult to resist as the young women who leave find themselves without any prospects of another job. A young woman complaining of sexual harassment over a long period said, when asked why she'd put up with it, 'I knew it was the only job I'd ever have.'
That quote is on page 157 of the report. The following paragraph on page 158 states:

Most of the women who complain of sexual harassment are, perhaps not surprisingly, somewhat timid in what they ask for by way of resolution. Many merely want the employers told that their behaviour is in breach of the Act. They hope that, by complaining, they can prevent other women from being subjected to the same sort of treatment. Other complainants wish merely to receive a reference, which is often denied. A very small number of complainants seek compensation either in the form of financial damages or in disciplinary action against the alleged harasser.

If the Deputy Prime Minister can assure the Committee that it is those blatant cases with which the Act is primarily concerned, and in the event of there being a trumped up and greatly inflated allegation it would be sifted out in the conciliation process without there being undue pressure on an employer to admit to something which in fact was not a grevious harassment of the order described, I think many of the fears reflected in this amendment would be abated. There is concern about the attention that men have given over the years, undoubtedly of a sexist character but perhaps not sexual in the strongest sense; such attention might suddenly now be paid. We know very well that men have sometimes subconsciously viewed women as sex objects. We know very well that 20 years ago or 10 years ago a pat on the bottom was regarded as somehow appropriate conduct on the part of men. It was accepted or tolerated by women without necessarily being welcomed. Certainly, if women had patted males on the bottom it would have been regarded as odd, and may even have been the cause of a reprimand.

The truth is that individuals have the right not to be touched or interfered with, as a matter of privacy and dignity. It is also true that in a hierarchical situation timid people find it hard to communicate their dislike of unwelcome attention from a superior. We accept all of that, but I am sure that the Committee will appreciate that these amendments are aimed at ensuring a safeguard from vexatious allegations of harassment which could result from a subconscious, paternalistic, certainly sexist, but not meant to be harassing, sexual act on the part of a male superior. If the Deputy Prime Minister has not fully grasped the degree of concern, I may intervene later in the debate on this clause. I think that the Deputy Prime Minister understands the concern and a reading of the amendment indicates that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayer Mrs H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment moved by the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) concerns me specifically because it states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: (b) the other person takes reasonable steps to communicate to the first- mentioned person that the advance, request or conduct is unwelcome;

I believe we have to ask ourselves what are the reasonable steps to take in the situation that the honourable member for Balaclava has already described in which a young and inexperienced person is being sexually harassed by an older person who is in the position to dismiss that person. I believe that people in that situation wish to distance themselves from such behaviour and ought not be compelled to communicate directly with the person whose behaviour is being objected to. I think that amendment is an unreasonable expectation in the circumstances which have been so well documented in the report of the New South Wales Anti-Discrimination Board and of the report of the Victorian Commissioner for Equal Opportunity. It makes no allowance for the kinds of social situations which we find and which we know exist. They did not just exist 10 or 20 years ago. Patting on the bottom still exists here; one has only to sit in the members ' dining room and watch the behaviour of some honourable members towards those people who look after them.

I think it is important that we understand that that lack of power and confidence, shyness and embarrassment are all things which would make it impossible for the person who is receiving the objectionable behaviour to take reasonable steps towards communicating with that person. I would find no difficulty in doing that at all and because that is plain I am not the object of sexual harassment. Those women who are the object of sexual harassment are those who plainly are not experienced or confident enough to be able to object to it, or to know, even though they have the law backing them up, that that objection will be taken as serious. I believe that the amendment puts far too much responsibility on the victim and far too little responsibility on the harasser.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in full sympathy with the remarks of the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer). I was not suggesting that physical molestation and harassment had ceased, merely that people are now aware of it and those who continue that practice do so at their own risk not only because of this legislation but also because of rebuke from the women concerned and from other men, if they are aware of it. I was merely indicating that because old habits die hard and old attitudes are hard to change there is a fear amongst some men who now accept that such behaviour was wrong. Nonetheless it is really hard to satisfy them that any other action they might take will not amount in someone's eyes to harassment because of the subjective nature of the tests involved.

SPEECH.PARA: I will use an illustration which I do not think will offend the people involved . When you, Madam Chairman, were elected as Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives, you were congratulated by the honourable member for Wide Bay ( Mr Millar), the person whom you beat in the ballot. He is a person whom all honourable members respect, and for whom you said you had considerable affection . He congratulated you by saying that it was a very nice thing that the fair sex was now represented in this exalted position. That was not meant to be patronising or sexist. It was a remark made by a gentleman whose view towards the way in which women should be treated differs only in its manner from the view of others. Younger men would not think that it was a necessary act of grace to make that remark. Men from the same generation as the honourable member or those with the same Australian male outlook might engage in other conduct which could be regarded as sexist, paternalistic but not meant to be harassing. They are afraid that they might, through conduct which they did not regard as being unwelcome, land in court or in the public eye. They are afraid that even within the group in which they mix or in their own office they might be seen as some sexual deviant who harassed people, and this is the problem.

The amendment is based a little on the judgment of Judge Jane Mathews, made on 21 June 1983, in the Loder case. It draws a little from some of what Her Honour had to say. Indeed, substantial extracts from the judgment appear at pages 158 and following of the New South Wales Anti-Discrimination Board report. For example, Her Honour says, as is shown at the foot of page 159:

The employer must either know that his conduct is unwelcome, or the circumstances must be such that he should know it. In other words, conduct which is persisted with in the face of rejection from the employee is capable of being unlawful under this head. Conduct which is continued in the face of an equivocal response may or may not be so. In all cases it is a precondition of liability that the complainant show both that the conduct was unwelcome in fact and that the employer either knew or ought to have known of this.

That is where the problems arise because the timidity of some of the women who are undoubtedly harassed is such that they find it exceedingly difficult to say to a superior: 'No, I don't like that kind of attention; I don't like that language' or whatever. Her Honour goes on:

A further breach of section 25(2)(a) can occur when an employer secures compliance with his sexual demands by threatening adverse employment consequences. The Tribunal will no doubt tread cautiously in relation to claims of sexual harassment made by employees who have entered into sexual relationships with their employers, for such relationships usually have the quality of mutuality.

Those extracts illustrate the difficulties that the Human Rights Commission will face in administering this legislation. Since the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has already said that these amendments will not be accepted, the Opposition is anxious that it at least be given an assurance by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) that in the event of rigidities and injustices appearing the Government will examine ways, either procedurally through the Human Rights Commission, or by an amendment of the Act, to ensure that there will not be an over-reaction to the extent that these provisions are abused and result in bogus complaints being made-complaints which, in the course of being found to be bogus , might cause a great deal of embarrassment to an innocent employer or superior, who might be hauled before at least a conciliation process, such that people will begin to say that yes, he is alleged to have sexually harassed somebody. The very word 'harassment' is somewhat technical. As the Deputy Prime Minister knows only too well, in relation to such terms as battery and assault, technically an assault can be verbal, it need not amount to a major bashing up that lands someone in hospital. In the same way a slight act can be an harassment, although, of course it ought to be repetition and so on.

I hope that the Government, though it will not accept these amendments, will appreciate the spirit in which they are offered. The Opposition, without wanting to jeopardise the objectives of the Bill, submits that the procedures set out in these amendments are not unreasonable. Briefly, they refer to the fact that the first-mentioned person must actually make an advance, there must be a series of communications concerning the unwelcomeness of the conduct, its persistence, and evidence of it. There will be quite a lot of concern simply because the social debate is now a confused one. We all accept that and know the reasons why.

A good many people will never change their sexist approach, yet they will try to come to grips with this in good faith.They will not be persistently, stubbornly, deliberately sexist but they will be unconsciously so because this legislation represents quite a remarkable break with the patterns of the past. I feel that such people need to be satisfied that they are not going to find themselves exposed to all sorts of trumped-up charges. We see it every day. Allegations appear not only in such publications as the Toorak Times and the Truth. What we have to get through to the distinguished Opposition is that there is another test here. It has been put to me that there is a requirement that , as well as the conduct being unwelcome, the complainant must also show on reasonable grounds that there has been a disadvantage.

The legislation is not aimed at friendly comments made to a work mate about appearance or opening doors or anything of that nature. There needs to be the other objective test that the person concerned must believe on reasonable grounds that there is going to be discrimination. Therefore, I think that what we are saying to honourable gentlemen opposite is that this is a very normal approach to a difficult area of definition. For example, the amendment does not clearly indicate how the harassee is supposed to communicate his or her objection. The Commission has been given sufficient powers to investigate the books of any political party if it is not satisfied with the returns given by those political parties following the next national election.

ANSWER.PARA: To some extent we are aware that people may be setting up front organisations. Laws in the United States have been to some extent circumvented by the setting up of front organisations to work on behalf of candidates or businessmen for the return of Democrat candidates, or whatever the party may be in the United States . The same thing may be occurring here through such establishments as the Bjelke -Petersen Foundation fund or the person who in conservative forces appears to have put as his objective becoming the next leader of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr Elliott. He seems to have set up this 500 Club, in which he is going to ask for $500 from 500 businessmen in order that he can propel himself into the leadership of the Liberal Party. If such organisations are carrying out the legitimate aims for which they were set up and if they are not interfering with the electoral processes, they have no need to worry. But if they are trying by some means to circumvent the laws which have been established in Australia and to push money into political parties of whatever persuasion-the conservative parties, the Australian Labor Party or the Australian Democrats-the Electoral Commission will have sufficient power to look at the books of those parties to make sure everything that is done is above board.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question, which concerns the Sala case, to the Deputy Prime Minister. Will the Deputy Prime Minister state whether a comprehensive file was completed on this matter? Does it still exist? If not, when was it destroyed?
