—Let me make it very clear: I am not aware of any inquiry in 1974 . Accordingly, I am not aware of any file that might have existed and been subsequently destroyed.
—Perhaps you could ask the Attorney to ask the police.

—I am quite happy to ask the Attorney about the honourable gentleman's question. But in view of the fact that we lost government in 1975, I would have thought the Opposition would have had access to some of this information.
—We did not go back into the files of other governments. We abide by the conventions. We did not go back into the files of other governments.
—Order! The House will come to order. I remind honourable members that they are only being filmed; sound is not being recorded.

—I am not anxious to get too much of the camera, either. The point I make is that at the moment I am not aware of any inquiry. The honourable gentleman must have some information that it was in fact made. If so, I would welcome further information as to who conducted the inquiry and what was its basis. It virtually destroys the objection now made by the Leader of the Opposition. If there was an inquiry it is pretty obvious that somebody in the successive governments from 1975 would have known about it.
—Those files were not made available at the change of government.

—We are talking about the inquiry that would have been made. Who would have made the inquiry is the point. It strikes me as being rather extraordinary that the Attorney-General in 1974 arranged for an inquiry and then arranged for its destruction. I cannot imagine the situation. But if the honourable gentleman has some further information that would help to identify the mysterious document, which is now, what, 10 years old-that shows the validity of what the Opposition is about today; it is 10 years behind-I will do the best I can to answer the question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. I preface my question by expressing my appreciation of the efficacy of the arrangements which have been made to introduce the Medicare scheme, including in my electorate of Kingston. Given the flexibility of the scheme and the flexibility which the Minister has used in introducing it, I ask him: Is he aware that a number of people would wish to obtain receipts for cash payments when they get a refund from Medicare? If that is so, is he able to outline to the House what arrangements he has made to give effect to that wish?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the issue raised by the honourable member for Kingston. Let me first of all explain to the House why we made the decision not to return account documents. The first reason for that is simply that the opportunities for account manipulation which have been identified in the past would not be possible if the documents were not retained. The second reason is that we need to have an effective pursuit of fraud and overservicing. As previous Health Ministers know, there are difficulties if those documents are not retained. A third reason is that we desired to have in our Medicare offices the most efficient claim turnover and payment system possible. Again, that was facilitated by not providing receipts and by not returning these documents.

ANSWER.PARA: However, there were clear protections introduced for people in such cases. First, we arranged with the Australian Taxation Office that everybody could claim from Medicare at the end of the financial year a full printout of all their payments and this would be acceptable to the Taxation Office when people made their claims. Secondly, if people did not want to have a cash payment they could, of course, have a cheque and the attachment to that cheque is acceptable to the Taxation Office for taxation claims. Nevertheless, I recognised that despite those protections there was still some anxiety about this issue. Last week we instructed the Health Insurance Commission to provide receipts to cash claimers who requested them. A notice to that effect will be put in Medicare offices. I hope within a fortnight those receipts will be available with cash claims.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister and it relates to the gravity of the allegations made against Mr Justice Murphy and others. As the Government will not accept the Opposition's call for a royal commission--

—If the Government really wanted the truth it would follow our call and would follow the Constitution. The Constitution is quite clear as to what course of action ought to be taken. It is this Parliament that deals with it.

—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will proceed with his question. Honourable members will cease interjecting. The Chair has to give very serious consideration to the question being asked because of the Standing Orders of the House and I want to be able to hear the question.

—The question relates to the gravity of the allegations made against Mr Justice Murphy and others. As the Government will not accept the Opposition's call for a royal commission, will the Prime Minister support the establishment of a joint select committee of the Parliament to inquire into and report on the allegations to enable the Parliament to meet its constitutional requirements on the basis that the inquiry not commence until after the holding of the New South Wales State election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, at last they have been forced out. We have witnessed in this country in the last few days the most despicable behaviour imaginable on the part of any opposition. The Opposition went through last week being simon- pure. That was not good enough. This week what do we have? We have an exhibition where the Leader of the Opposition was either engaged in duplicity or was not the Leader of the Opposition because he talked to the Press and said: 'Of course , we would not bring out the name of the judge'. While he was saying that, the honourable member for Boothby in this House identified the judge. The Leader of the Opposition was either lying to the media or had no control over the members of his Opposition.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. Only one man in the past two days has lied in this Parliament, and that is the Prime Minister.

—Order! There is an increasing practice in the House for members to accuse one another of lying. This is unparliamentary language. I ask that honourable members do not use that language. I call the Leader of the Opposition on his point of order.

—The point of order is that when the honourable member for Boothby made that statement the other day, I was in the chamber and was with him. I heard it. I was not at a Press conference. I held the Press conference subsequently.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.
—The point is that the Prime Minister as usual places more reliance on what is written about the Parliament than what actually transpires.
—Order! I warn the Leader of the Opposition that, while because of his position he receives tolerance from the Chair, he should not abuse that tolerance. I call the Prime Minister.

—We then move from the position of the devious activities of Opposition members in this place to their allowing their colleagues in another institution to descend even further into the gutter which they have occupied so conspicuously this week. I made quite clear in the House yesterday the position in regard to the constitutional division of power between the Parliament, the Executive and the judiciary. Let me remind the House today, but before I do I pick up the phraseology used by the Leader of the Opposition in his question. I have noted his words. He referred to 'the gravity of the allegations' against the judge. Where are these allegations?
—They are in the tapes that you would not listen to.
—Order! The honourable member for Denison will cease interjecting.
—We get the answer by way of interjection. When I asked: 'Where are these allegations, the gravity of which is alluded to?', the honourable member for Denison says: 'They are in the tapes'.
—Which you won't listen to.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Denison.

—So out of the mouth of the honourable member for Denison this despicable scenario is again being made clear. The law of this country was broken in the taking of unauthenticated tapes, involving a gross invasion of the privacy of individuals. On that basis the Opposition, now endorsed by the honourable member for Denison, says: 'That is where we have the gravity of the allegations'. Let every member of this country understand the standards of decency of Opposition members. It is saying that where one has a breaking of the law, unauthenticated tapes, a gross invasion of privacy, that involves grave allegations and this Parliament should drag into the chamber the reputations of decent Australians. I repeat: That is the situation that the Opposition wants to establish.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said, the Opposition has been universally branded now as an opposition totally incapable of discharging the normal obligations of an opposition. It is incapable of either examining the policies of the Government or putting up policies of its own. It is universally condemned as incompetent. Now it wants to establish a standard in this place, so that the Parliament, as a result of the Opposition's incompetence in discharging the normal functions of an opposition, will have to say of those illegal operations, unauthenticated tapes and invasions of privacy, that there are grave allegations. Do honourable members opposite mean that every time there is a breaking of the law or an invasion of the privacy of citizens on the telephones of this country they will say that the right course for this Parliament is to say: 'Yes, grave allegations are involved in that illegal action and we will immediately move'? I remind the House--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have a duty to protect the public.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition offends again.
—You have a duty to protect the public and that overrides privacy and privilege.
—Order! I warn the Leader of the Opposition.

—I will remind the House of what I told it yesterday, but I will preface that by saying that this Government will neither confirm nor deny the names of anyone involved in the tapes and the transcripts. I believe there are still some honourable members left on the other side of the House, and I remind them that the legal opinions of the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Temby, and the Solicitor-General, Dr Griffith, demonstrate that judicial misbehaviour as used in the Constitution involves either matters pertaining to a person's performance as a judge in his judicial office or criminal misconduct which would make it inappropriate for a judge to stay in office. That is the opinion of the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Solicitor-General. As I told the House yesterday, there is no suggestion of the first condition applying, while opinions from the Australian Federal Police, the New South Wales Solicitor- General, and Mr Temby have indicated that no criminal misconduct by the judge would be indicated in the facts revealed by the tapes and the transcripts, even if they were authenticated, which they are not. As there is absolutely nothing which could justify a substantive motion by the Parliament on this subject, there is no conceivable basis on which any action of the sort suggested by the Leader of the Opposition should be taken.

ANSWER.PARA: I also remind the House that other matters raised by the tapes are being investigated vigorously and competently. The Director of Public Prosecutions is supervising investigations by a joint New South Wales-Australian Federal Police investigating team charged with bringing prosecutions for any breaches of federal law which may be revealed. I also remind the House that relevant material has been forwarded to Mr Justice Stewart and to Special Prosecutor Redlich.

The position is quite clear. Honourable members on the other side of the House are suggesting-look at the hypocrisy of what is involved-that they are interested in protecting proper standards of behaviour, that the behaviour of a judge is in question. In terms of going to a question of proper standards of behaviour, this Opposition is following a course of behaviour which can only bring it into contempt. If this Parliament were minded to go down this course it would only bring the Parliament into contempt.

I say finally that the public of Australia will judge, and will judge harshly, an Opposition which without question is trying to establish-I again remind the House and the people of Australia of just what this Opposition is trying to do- because it has no positive case in respect of the actions of this Government, which has acted expeditiously and with total propriety on this matter--

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you squibbing it for, Hawke?
—I warn the Leader of the National Party.

—Honourable members opposite are seeking to establish a McCarthyist position in this country whereby the conversations of private citizens on the telephone can be tapped illegally and then, on the basis of an illegal tapping they will seek to say: 'Those are grave allegations involving the breaking of the law; let us move'.

ANSWER.PARA: What we have done, with total propriety, is this: Immediately these matters came to the attention of the Attorney-General they were referred, as they should have been, to the Australian Federal Police. They were referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions and to the Solicitor-General. What the Opposition is saying now is that the Government having followed that course of action, which is a totally proper way of ensuring that the privileges and rights of this Parliament are not going to be abused in the way the Opposition would wish, as they were in regard to Mr Justice Cross, it does not believe that one can rely on the Australian Federal Police. It is saying that one cannot rely on Mr Temby, that one cannot rely on the Solicitor-General. First of all it was 'Attack Mr Justice Cross'. Now it is 'Attack the Solicitor-General'. Honourable members opposite can do all the attacking that they like. The end result will be that they will go further down, if that is possible, in the estimation of the people of Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the intention--
—I take a point of order. The Minister has no responsibility for the Queensland Parliament. I suggest that the question is out of order.
—I think the matter refers to a police investigation. The Special Minister of State is concerned with the Australian Federal Police.
—That was not the question.

—You can read it in. This Government does not intend to add any dignity to the comments made yesterday in the Queensland Parliament by the Minister for Transport, Mr Lane, who is commonly known in Queensland, as I understand it from Mr Moore, as Shady Lane. Mr Lane has been a member of a number of parties. There seems to be something wrong with the mentality of people who keep changing parties. I notice that the honourable member for Boothby has been in more parties than was Billy Hughes.
—I ask the Special Minister to get to his answer.
—It is interesting to connect what happened in the Queensland Parliament previously with the statements made by Mr Lane yesterday.
—It has nothing to do with your responsibility.
—It has something to do with my responsibility. How do we know how Mr Lane is able to verify names that are on the tapes? Does Mr Lane have the tapes?
—They are your tapes, are they? They are not Federal Police tapes, Mick?
—I think the Leader of the National Party has them because he could not help himself picking them up if he saw them somewhere.
—I ask the Special Minister of State, in answering the question, to help preserve order in the House. It has been a very black day for the House in respect of behaviour.

—It is necessary to make some comment on what was done yesterday in the Queensland Parliament. It is not our intention to take any action in relation to this, or to add dignity to what occurred yesterday in the Queensland Parliament, but it is interesting to relate it to what happened in the Queensland Parliament previously on this question. I refer to Queensland Hansard of 9 December 1975, when a one-day sitting of the Parliament was called just prior to the election in that year. The Queensland Premier said:

ANSWER.PARA: As a member of the Australian Loan Council, I saw it as my duty to have such inquiries made on my behalf.
The reference is to loans. He continued:

Those inquiries have now been made. As a result, I am in possession of considerably more material, which satisfies me that I was completely justified in having those inquiries carried out. In one deal alone, it is now clear that two Ministers of the Whitlam Government, together with a number of other people, were due to receive staggering sums of money as a consequence of secret commissions and kick-backs.
I invite honourable members to look at the interjection by Mr Hinze:
Murphy will be a surfie by the time we're finished with him.

So the campaign goes on. From the end of 1975, when Justice Murphy of the High Court of Australia was Senator Murphy, comments were being made in the Queensland Parliament that the Queensland conservatives, the Nationals, intended to get him; so there is no fluke involved.

Let us look at Mr Lane's activities this year. He switched from the Liberal Party to the National Party after the election to retain his ministry. To whom does he owe a debt now? He owes it to the Queensland Premier. When he was called upon yesterday to deliver the goods he was not afraid to get up and name people because he owed that debt to the Queensland Premier. I ask honourable members opposite to listen to the honourable member from Bass when he makes his personal explanation after Question Time, because they can all find themselves in the position in which Mr Lane put citizens of this country yesterday.

Mr Lane does not happen to have a very happy background. He was the person who, according to reliable sources in Queensland, was responsible for condemning the late Mr Justice Douglas and preventing him from becoming Chief Justice of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do ask the Special Minister of State to round off his answer. He is ranging rather widely.

—I was about to conclude, Mr Speaker. One of Mr Lane's more momentous achievements in the Queensland police force, in which he served before he became a member, was the arrest of a man in Brisbane on a charge of using obscene language. It was subsequently discovered that the man was deaf and dumb. Now, since Mr Lane has changed his Party, they have changed his name from Shady Lane to Changing Lane.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is too late now, but what the Minister has just done I believe completely transgresses Standing Orders.

—I ask the Minister who represents the Attorney-General whether he is satisfied that absence of criminal or constitutionally improper behaviour is, on its own, adequate criterion for determining the suitability of a person to occupy high judicial office or whether there are other standards of behaviour also to be met? Will the Minister ask the Attorney-General to consult with the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia on the question of whether Mr Justice Murphy should stand down from the Bench until doubts about his suitability for high judicial office are resolved?

—I think this is an outrageous question. It certainly contravenes standing order 75 of this House in that in the thrust of the question there is an inference that there is some validity in the charges made by the honourable member who asked the question. He well knows that all information made available to the Government--
—Has not been provided to the Parliament.

—was given to the Solicitor-General. I do not want any help from the right honourable member. That would be the last thing I would want. It was given to the Solicitor-General and the Director of Public Prosecutions. It was said that there was no evidence at all that would justify any accusation that is now being made. There is no point at all in discussing the matter with the Chief Justice. The issue is the question of misbehaviour as defined under section 72. That is the issue.
—That is the one the Prime Minister puts down. He won't even entertain it.
—If we could just get the honourable member to concentrate on the issue.
—You have to know that that is the fundamental one, and you are right in raising it.

—The fundamental issue is, of course, that there is nobody able to come forward with any evidence. We have a thing called a tape and we have something called a transcript that was made by somebody. Of course, the person who made it has already breached the Telecommunications (Interception) Act and is liable to penalties of imprisonment and fine. So perhaps that is the reason why some honourable members opposite do not want to come forward. However, on the question of proof, if in fact somebody did the interception, that person would be able to give evidence. So where is that person? Why can we not find that person?
—You have had four months to find them.

—Look, honourable members opposite have had them for four months and they could be in their cohorts over there. The Opposition adopts the outrageous position of using somebody in the Queensland Parliament to name a member of the High Court. Today it compounded the same detraction by naming the person again with not one tittle of evidence as to the validity of the tape or the validity of the transcript. There are people, obviously-perhaps Bob Bottom knows them-who did this action. They exist, and that is where the Opposition wants to get its evidence from.

—I direct my question, which regards policy and not gutter talk, to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Can the Minister inform the House of any action taken by the Government to assist the East Timorese to obtain reunion with their families in Australia following the continuing strife in their own country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has been continually concerned to effect the ongoing family reunion of people from East Timor. Already 5,000 people from East Timor have been successfully resettled in Australia. Following representations from our Foreign Minister, the Government has pressed for the conclusion of the list- cases of some 600 for family reunion in Australia from Indonesia and East Timor. Due to the efforts of the Foreign Minister and this Government some 61 persons from East Timor of the list-cases have effected family reunion in Australia since last April. There are in fact only two cases left on the list.

ANSWER.PARA: However, there is another group of people from East Timor that the Government is now addressing. They are people who left East Timor for Portugal and countries other than Australia since 1975. This is a rather complex situation that the Government is anxious to bring to a successful conclusion. Back in October 1980 the previous Government established a special humanitarian program for East Timorese who were resident outside East Timor, for example in Portugal, Taiwan or Macao. But that Government set a cutoff point for eligibility for family reunion to Australia from such countries as Portugal. That cutoff point was 30 September 1980. Some 2,400 people have reached Australia under the special humanitarian program. However, the result of that decision was twofold. Firstly, it established a program of a special nature outside the usual parameters of the special humanitarian program, that is, we were accepting people who had been successfully settled in a third country. Obviously, we cannot let that go on forever. Secondly, the decision to establish an arbitrary line of 30 September 1980 really rules quite unfairly against people who have reached Portugal since that date. The fact is that the previous Government only went half way and left an ongoing anomaly. Therefore, in order both to wind up the anomalous nature of this program and, further, to give justice to all of the East Timorese who fled East Timor in 1975, the Government has decided to advance the 30 September 1980 cutoff line so that East Timorese in third countries with a family reunion connection as at 29 February 1984 have six months to be sponsored from Australia under the special humanitarian program and a further six months to finalise movement to Australia. That will wind up an anomalous situation and at the same time give justice to all East Timorese who went to Portugal and other countries after 1975.

At the conclusion of this specified period of one year all East Timorese will then have their claims considered within the provisions of the normal migration program. This would include family reunion and the special humanitarian program while the normal family reunion criteria and independent migration procedures would apply to those East Timorese with resident status in other countries. In conclusion, what we are doing, of course, is winding up an anomalous situation regarding East Timorese presently in Portugal and bringing all East Timorese, wherever they may be, including those people now in East Timor, into a normal refugee and family migration situation. This will depend on ongoing negotiations with the Indonesian Government.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT AND CONSERVATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received advice from the Government Whip that he has nominated the honourable member for Tangney, Mr Gear, to be a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation in place of Mr Reeves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On 18 May 1983, I outlined in this Parliament an immigration intake for 1983-84 involving categories of family reunion, labour shortage and business migration, special eligibility and refugees. I said that this Australian Labor Party Government would give priority to family reunion and refugees. This reflected our view that in times of economic recession our first commitment would be to honour responsibilities to those migrants already in Australia, to honour international obligations and to accept that humanitarian considerations applied to both these areas. The former Government had given priority to migration which filled alleged labour shortages within Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the framework outlined above, I foreshadowed a migration intake made up as follows: family migration between 51,000-57,000; independent and occupations in demand, lowering a number of categories up to 13,000; and refugees between 18 ,000-20,000.

In 1982-83, under the program initiated by the former Government, the actual intake was 27,000 family migration; 17,000 refugees and special humanitarian programs; 32,000 for labour shortage and business migration; 6,490 independent migrants; and 570 special eligibility, making a total of approximately 83,000 arrivals. The changes introduced by this Government were intended to reduce migration based upon alleged labour shortage; that is, persons very likely without family in Australia, and to increase family migration.

I also said that there would be a diversification of countries from which refugees would be accepted. This diversification was based on a recognition of the many migrant groups represented in our society, the concern these groups have for people affected by strife in their home countries and Australia's basic humanitarian objectives. I also said visa free entry under the trans-Tasman travel arrangements would continue.

I have just completed a half-yearly review of the program, and will now detail emerging trends and developments that will affect the outcome of this year's program. The forward estimates are substantially correct, except for family reunion, under special category C; that is brothers, sisters, and non-dependent children. Information now available shows that numbers admitted under this category will be fewer than anticipated. I now expect that not more than 16,000 will be visaed under this category.

Family reunion numbers under categories A and B should be much as predicted; that is up to 27,000, giving a family migration result for 1983-84 of up to 43, 000 visaed arrivals. Approximately 17,000 should be admitted under our refugee and special humanitarian program and 10,000-11,000 in occupations in demand and business migration. Total intake for 1983-84 should be approximately 70,000. The emerging change on forward assessments is specifically in category C; that is brothers, sisters and non-dependent children, with very sound reasons for this change. There has been a lessening interest amongst permanent residents and Australian citizens towards sponsoring family members from Europe and the United Kingdom. This is not a surprising development. Many of the migrants have been in Australia for a long time with many immediate family members already here. Prospective migrants are sensitive to changing economic conditions both here and in their own countries. For example, those who are already gainfully employed in their homelands must measure the relative merits of family reunion against their prospects in Australia. There is evidence that many such people, possibly contrary to the expectations of their sponsoring families in Australia, are opting to remain at home or to defer the decision to migrate.

In illustrating this, as a percentage total sponsorships from July to December 1983, 9.3 per cent related to United Kingdom and Eire, 1.4 per cent to Poland, 0 .8 per cent to Greece, 0.8 per cent to Italy, 1.7 per cent to Yugoslavia and 9.5 per cent to all other European countries. European sponsorships total 23.4 per cent of the total sponsorships for that half year. This compares with Lebanon with 5.8 per cent, and a Middle East total of 13.3 per cent. The comparative figures from Asia, to give some examples, were 2.9 per cent Philippines, 13.4 per cent Sri Lanka and 25.8 per cent to other Asian countries, including the orderly departure program from Vietnam. In addition, many sponsorships were not taken up by sponsored relatives in Europe. These figures are as high as 60 per cent in Athens, 25 per cent in Rome, and 30 per cent in Belgrade.

We are still requiring offers of employment to be made for prospective category C migrants. This can create a problem for potential family reunion applicants. It is also difficult to check job offers and to monitor take-up rates. The alternative would be simply to delete this requirement and accept higher migrant unemployment and associated settlement problems. My Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is presently reviewing the effectiveness of the job offer requirement. During April 1984, a survey of 300 migrants under the job offer arrangement will be conducted. I hope this will allow for more informed decisions to be made on the job offer requirement for the 1984-85 intake. In the interim, and for the remainder of the 1983-84 year, the Government will maintain the requirement for arranged employment for category C migrants. Job offers are not required for spouses, refugees or migrants under special humanitarian programs.

Given that there is a reduction in sponsorships, as outlined, and the fact that some people are still, even with a job offer, not achieving enough points under the points assessment system, I have given consideration to reducing educational or skill standards and/or giving more points to older persons. However, on balance the Government feels that the changes made to the points assessment systems last May have already significantly moderated previous bias in favour of highly skilled, English-speaking, youthful and affluent migrants. The option of a further relaxation of the points assessment system would have the effect of increasing numbers of semi-skilled or unskilled persons, many of them elderly, seeking to enter Australia. This would have to be carefully assessed, even in a period of economic recovery and reducing unemployment. Nevertheless, the Government repudiates ill-informed criticism that it has not honoured its family reunion undertakings. It has clearly done so and will continue to do so.

Under the previous Government, family migration fell from a forward estimate for 1982-83 of 44,000 to only 27,000. I envisage now after the half-yearly review that family reunion in 1983-84 in all categories will, from a maximum forward estimate of 57,000, be between 38,000 and 43,000 visaed migrants.

TALK.START.PARA: —We told you you would not meet the targets.

—We are pretty much more on target than the former Government was the previous year. It is difficult, for the reasons I have enunciated, to stay with forward estimates. They are not targets, they are ceilings, by the way, as the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), and the former Ministers would know. This figure of up to 43,000 visaed migrants in family reunion categories is a significant increase over family reunion migration in 1982-83.

SPEECH.PARA: Our refugee and special humanitarian programs have been diversified, as foreshadowed in my first statement on Australia's immigration program. In 1982- 83 27 per cent of the program was other than Asian. This year the non-Asian component will be around 40 per cent. That is as a result of the diversification of source countries. In 1982-83, 16,294 refugees and 760 under the special humanitarian program entered Australia. A total of 12,435 of the refugees were from Indo-China; the orderly departure or family reunion program from Vietnam totalled 550. In 1983-84 there should be 10,000 Indo-Chinese refugees, with an additional emphasis on orderly departure from Vietnam; that is up to 2,000. Other changes are: From Latin America from 50 in 1982-83 up to 1,300 in 1983-84; a moderate reduction in the Eastern European refugee program where applications have fallen off; also, humanitarian entry has been applied or extended to include the Lebanon, Sri Lanka, East Timor and the Middle East, including Christian Assyrians from Athens and Rome. These actions have, on the one hand, answered anxieties in the Australian community and, on the other hand, strengthened Australia's reputation as a pace setter in humanitarian efforts world wide.

Given all these factors, there is one charge levelled by a prejudiced minority and supported by the Opposition which I should now completely repudiate; that is , that this Government is discriminating against Europeans and citizens of the United Kingdom. Further, some groups in Australia assert that we are downgrading European migration in favour of Asians. Here I must question the honesty of these charges and assertions which talk about migration in unacceptably racial terms.

Firstly some facts. There is no discrimination evident in any part or aspect of Australia's immigration program. The Government has assiduously worked to ensure that there is no discrimination on the basis of race, sex or religious persuasions. The Asian percentage of the total migration program is rising but this is not as a result of any discrimination. It is a natural outcome of the factors I have just alerted honourable members to; that is, lessening interest in sponsorships from migrants in traditional source countries, the growing diversification of our refugee program and the strong priority given by this and recent Australian governments to the reunion of families, particularly those in tragic circumstances of war and civil strife. To allege that this is discrimination is a vicious, destructive and irresponsible misrepresentation of what this Government and its predecessor have done.

I remind the House that it was our conservative predecessors who first involved Australia in Vietnam, quite incorrectly, but then correctly commenced the current Indo-Chinese refugee program. The massive exodus of Indo-Chinese from Vietnam which commenced in the late 1970s saw huge numbers of refugees arriving in Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines, and a small number of direct arrivals in Australia. The international community responded to the needs of these people by undertaking resettlement programs for people who could not hope to return to their homelands. It is widely accepted that long term residence in refugee camps is the least desirable solution to such problems. These problems in South East Asia were, of course, complicated by the addition of Laotian and Khmer refugees to the already huge task of coping with the mass exodus of Vietnamese.

Australia and the international community has responded to the plight of all of these people through co-ordinated programs of protection, resettlement and financial assistance. Whilst humanitarian considerations dictate that resettlement is still necessary, this Government maintains strongly that solutions must be found to the cause of mass population movements in South East Asia. This Labor Government has also consistently said that the top priority is to achieve a situation where Vietnamese, Lao and Khmers presently in camps in South East Asia could confidently return to their homelands. We are also supporting a widening of the orderly departure or family reunion program from Vietnam as an alternative to illegal departures.

Because of these goals I attended inter-governmental consultations in Honolulu last year involving the United States of America, Canada, Japan and Australia. I then visited Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia and Thailand, where I stressed that resettlement alone was not the answer. On behalf of the Government, I stressed the need for voluntary repatriation to countries of origin and orderly departure from Vietnam, and for increased involvement by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to implement these aims. I found substantial support among resettlement countries and also from the member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations in the region.

I have recently participated in discussions in Canberra with Mr Poul Hartling, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, who visited Australia as a guest of government from 15 to 21 February last. It has been established that the voluntary repatriation of Lao refugees has resumed to the extent that during 1983 some 600 have been repatriated. That is a very significant step towards achieving a lasting solution to the refugee problems of South East Asia. Mr Hartling particularly welcomed this Government's move to a global approach in responding to refugee needs, an approach which reflects the broad aims of the office of the UNHCR. The Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, and I will further stress the refugee policies of the Australian Government, including our interest in voluntary repatriation and the orderly departure program, when the Foreign Ministers of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam and Thailand visit Australia in the near future.

So we have moved from a simple resettlement policy to a policy which seeks a variety of long term solutions to a complex problem. This Government does not accept criticism regarding Asianisation of our migration or refugee programs. I repeat: This Government is moderately reducing the Indo-Chinese refugee intake from the camps in ASEAN countries whilst increasing direct family reunion from Vietnam and continually searching for alternatives to resettlement. We thus act to maintain our international humanitarian commitments whilst simultaneously seeking stability within our region.

I urge the Opposition immigration spokesman and his Leader to refrain from any misrepresentation of complex policies which they themselves commenced and which we are continually modifying and widening as we seek to honour both our regional and global humanitarian responsibilities. I urge the Opposition not to lend its support to any possible emerging anti-Asian racism within Australia. Attacks suggesting that we are discriminating against British and European settlers are often barely concealed racism. Through its generous and wholehearted response to the claims of Indo-Chinese refugees and migration sponsors, the Australian community and successive Governments have laid to rest for ever any remnants of a White Australia image which used to damage us internationally. We must not reverse this process.

I also urge the Opposition to avoid being used by minority opinion in Australia which begrudges our helping Indo-Chinese refugees and their separated families. Such attitudes undermine Australia's established reputation as a refugee receiving country. Nothing could be more damaging to our current good relations with ASEAN and our regional standing than to unilaterally and suddenly withdraw from the Indo-Chinese refugee program. This would undermine the carefully developed understanding within the international community on how best to deal with refugee problems in our region and elsewhere.

Last March an election was fought and won on the issue of divisiveness within the Australian community created by the former Government's policies. We must ask ourselves whether it is responsible to conduct the immigration debate using arguments about how many people from particular racial groups should settle in Australia in any one program year. This is language calculated to divide the community and I and the Government reject it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are being very provocative.

—I am not being provocative. I repeat: There is no discrimination against British or European settlers by this Government. However, nor will we turn our backs on the Asian region. An increasing percentage of the total migration intake consists of Asians. That is a direct result of refugee policy. Those people then have family reunion rights. It is also a direct result of the lessening of interest, the lessening of sponsorship, from within Australia relating to the old traditional countries, for the reasons I have enunciated.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly the result of all this is an increasing Asian percentage but that is not evidence of discrimination against Britain or Europe and it is not evidence of a deliberate Asianisation of the program.

Last May I foreshadowed less reliance on migration of skilled workers and more emphasis on the training and retraining of Australians. I said-this is an important change-that the current system of selecting skilled migrants according to an occupational demand schedule, which is compiled half yearly, needed revision. The occupational demand schedule we inherited had limited capacity to cater for future demand, and was based on past labour shortages. Lags in processing, visa issue and travel arrangements often resulted in jobs allegedly in demand six months previously, not being available when the migrant arrived. Although these occupations in alleged demand have been reduced from approximately 80 categories a little more than a year ago to 13 today, the system is still unsatisfactory.

I said that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and I would look for alternatives to overseas recruitment of skilled workers based on a total labour force planning system. It will have the twin purpose of filling short term shortages and, in the long term, reducing our reliance on skilled migrants. It will involve integrating for the first time Australian labour planning, education and immigration policies. The new procedures are currently being developed, and are expected to apply from the beginning of the 1984-85 financial year. The system will involve a forward assessment of labour requirements in the approximately 60 major skilled occupations, in which international migration has recently played a significant role. The Department of Employment and Industrial Relations will provide an annual report on skilled labour market needs from which a ceiling of occupational annual shares will be set for skilled migration purposes. These ceilings will be reassessed half yearly by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, with quarterly consultations between the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The Department of Employment and Industrial Relations will also, where long term changes in the balance of educational effort are required, be in a position to advise the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's triennial planning process.

The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations also expects to use the recently announced review of Commonwealth labour market programs as a basis for developing and improving flexibility in training and retraining systems. The new strategy is to cover short term shortages and, in the long term, change the balance between domestic and overseas skilled labour supply to the benefit of workers within Australia. Honourable members will see what the Government is trying to do there. The present labour shortage and business migration category will be retitled 'the skilled labour and business migration program,' and the present occupation in demand category will be retitled 'skilled labour'. Since only 5,000-6,000 migrants will be admitted under the current occupational demand system in 1983-84 involving only 2,000-2,500 workers, it is probable that in 1984-85 as we implement the occupational share system, independent skilled labour migration could increase. However, as the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and I foreshadowed, long term planning is to reduce reliance on skilled labour migration, by using a totally integrated labour market planing approach involving forward planning by the departments of Employment and Industrial Relations, Education and Youth Affairs and Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

It is proposed to review the current employment scheme and temporary entry arrangements to ensure that requirements of employers are strictly applied, and that temporary entry is not used to bypass permanent entry controls. Nevertheless, I anticipate that employer nomination could be important in temporarily providing employment for skilled workers, on whom the development of industry and the employment of other local workers could be dependent. The Government will continue to support business migration provided the project is viable, provides permanent employment and/or new industries and technologies, and the proposer intends to reside permanently in Australia.

Mr Speaker, I have outlined again our migration program and informed the House of the latest emerging trends. I have explained how our expanded family reunion policy is being implemented, how our refugee and special humanitarian program is being diversified and, in particular, I have refuted misinformed claims of discrimination against European and UK citizens. I have explained briefly our proposed new system of selecting and admitting skilled labour, and indicated that this Government welcomes business migration if it is to Australia's benefit and creates permanent employment.

This is an enlightened, forward-looking humanitarian and internationally accepted program. It is supported by our ASEAN neighbours. The orderly departure program has the support of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam. I believe these achievements are significant. As well as implementing our own policies, we have refined, changed where necessary, moderated and diversified the programs we inherited from the previous Government. In many areas there is continuity; in others, there is change. The Government is continuing this mix of internationally accepted policies, recognising that Australia is a multicultural society, and that migrants are free to retain cultural links with their home countries while benefiting from their rights to goverment services and programs in Australia, without discrimination. I present the following paper:
Migration Program 1983-84-Ministerial Statement, 7 March 1984.

I have said it before and I will say it again: The radical and dangerous turn to the Left which has occurred in the area of immigration and ethnic affairs since the Hawke socialist Government came to power is not accepted by the people of Australia. Mark my words, it will cost the Government dearly at the next Federal election.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I have to say again that notwithstanding the sophistry of the Minister in his statement this afternoon he has failed to persuade me and, I suggest, the people of Australia that he is not pursuing immigration policies which are, without doubt, anti-British and anti-European in their bias. Thirdly, by the Minister's own admission he has politicised the one thing which was non- political in immigration and ethnic affairs, namely, the refugee intake. I will say something more about that later in my remarks.

I am forced again to criticise the Minister because he has virtually abolished deportation from this country. In his ministerial statement he did not mention the fact that we have now reached the incredible situation in Australia that we do not even have the power to deport a Soviet spy who has been a resident of this country for, say, 10 years. I wonder whether the people of Australia would be interested to know tle position in respect of a person who had resided in this country for 10 years and had not taken out citizenship and who had harboured Mr Ivanov. I say again to the Minister, in a friendly way, if I can put it to him in that way: Why is he not prepared to earn his salary by exercising his ministerial discretion? Since he became Minister he has refused point blank to exercise discretion in cases where persons in Australia on visas wish to seek permanent resident status, unless a person marries or unless there are special humanitarian grounds. Therefore, he has created a situation in which any person in Australia on a visa wishing to seek permanent resident status has to marry to gain such status. I suggest that is marvellous if, firstly, that person is already married or, secondly, that person does not want to get married.

It is because the Minister has failed to exercise his ministerial discretion properly that harsh and inhumane decisions, such as that which occurred in the Petrovski case, have unfortunately occurred. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's obstruction of the Parliament in the proper discharge of its constitutional responsibilities in relation to Federal Judges.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last few days in responding to questions both from the Government and from the Opposition on the Age tapes issue, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) among other things has sought to rely on two emotions. The first of these emotions is in a proper context, of course; a sense of indignity at unfair attacks upon the judiciary of Australia. Well it is that the Prime Minister of this country above everybody else should have a proper sense of concern about unfair attacks upon members of the judiciary. Over the past few days the Prime Minister has sought to characterise questions raised by the Opposition on this issue as being an improper use of parliamentary privilege to impugn the general integrity of the judiciary. It sits very ill for this man to try to raise a sense of righteous indignation about what we have said regarding allegations involving a Federal judge when one recalls what that same person said on 15 December 1979 when he was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: If ever people have to face their maker and justify their existence, certain occupants of the High Court will have a particularly messy time.

That quotation came from none other than the present Prime Minister of Australia . It demonstrates that when it comes to questioning about the judiciary, as with questioning about the use of deficit estimates, this Prime Minister is bedevilled with double standards. Not only has he been demonstrated to have double standards on this issue but also, during Question Time, he fulminated about the fact that these tapes were obtained in circumstances which involved some invasion of privacy. It may well be that obtaining the tapes involved some illegality. It may well be, as I understand to be the case, that that possible illegality should be investigated. But let me remind the House of two things: Firstly, when it came to using tapes that suited his own purpose in an industrial dispute 11 years ago, the present Prime Minister was monumentally unconcerned about the invasion of privacy that was involved. He enunciated a simple doctrine: If material raised in tapes is serious enough, it does not really matter how they were obtained. That was the doctrine according to Hawke in 1972. Secondly, the doctrine according to Hawke now is that if there is any taint of illegality in the obtaining of tapes, one must totally ignore them. Once again this Prime Minister is demonstrated to have monumental double standards.

The essence of this issue, as the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) acknowledged during Question Time, is the role of the Parliament. It is beyond argument that under section 72 of the Constitution of Australia the question of removal or dealing with Federal judges in relation to allegations of misbehaviour is something that belongs to this Parliament and to this Parliament alone. If one were to look at the debates of the Australian Constitutional Convention and to examine the ordinary, plain English meaning of the language of section 72 one is left with the absolutely irrefutable conclusion that it belongs to this Parliament and to this Parliament alone to determine questions of misbehaviour relating to Federal judges. The Government's weakest area and area of greatest vulnerability on this issue is its absolute refusal to acknowledge the right of this Parliament and this Parliament alone to determine questions of misbehaviour. By its actions and its obstruction, the Executive Government of this country at present is denying to the Parliament the right given to it under the Constitution.

What the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Prime Minister are doing-what no doubt the Deputy Prime Minister will do-is inviting this Parliament to the equivalent of passing a piece of legislation whilst denying the members of the Parliament a copy of the legislation in question. If we are to discharge our constitutional responsibility to adjudicate upon matters of misbehaviour, I ask you, Mr Speaker, how on earth can we exercise that responsibility unless we have the relevant material before us? When one goes through what the Government has done and said on this issue it is very interesting to note that, although it has obtained an opinion from Mr Temby on what he thinks constitutes misbehaviour and lack of judicial behaviour, and although it has obtained an opinion from the Solicitor-General about his definition of what constitutes misbehaviour under the Constitution, at no stage has this Attorney-General, this Prime Minister or this Government sought to obtain an opinion from anybody about the role of the Parliament in this issue. That is a very interesting omission. The reason for that omission is that the role of the Parliament in this issue is beyond argument and beyond contest. It is for the Parliament and the Parliament alone to decide questions of misbehaviour.

I make it quite clear so there will be no side argument: I cast no reflection on the integrity of either Mr Temby or the present Solicitor-General. The question of their integrity and competence really is irrelevant to the argument I am putting. My argument is a very simple one. It is the central issue in this whole debate; that is, whether we as the Parliament, as ordained by the Constitution, will have the right to do what the founding fathers wanted us to do. When one goes through the Convention debates-indeed, when one goes through the opinion of the Solicitor-General himself, an opinion on which the Attorney- General has sought to rely in rebutting the requests made by the Opposition not only here but also in another place-one finds an endorsement of the very proposition I am putting. I refer to page 7 of the opinion of the Solicitor- General, where he recites the debates and the movements of those debates at the Constitutional Convention regarding the question of the power of parliament to address for removal on grounds. Picking up the language of clause 12 of the opinion, he says:
The general discretionary power of Parliament to address for removal on grounds other than misbehaviour, in the technical sense understood by the delegates, was eliminated--
here are the important words-
with the function of finding such misbehaviour vested in the Parliament rather than in the Executive.

That is the opinion not of the Opposition, not of a member of the Opposition, but of the Government's second law officer. He is saying very clearly in that opinion that it is for the Parliament to make a decision on questions of misbehaviour. What is the response of the Attorney-General to this? I had a debate about this issue with the Attorney-General last night on the radio program PM. When I put the proposition that it really was the role of Parliament and that this was the central issue, his response was: 'Well, I get complaints about the peccadillos of Federal judges all the time. Do you mean to say that every time I get a letter from an aggrieved litigant complaining about the conduct of a Federal judge I have to run off to the Parliament and get the Parliament to have a look at it?'. I put it to you, Mr Speaker, that to compare what has happened on this occasion in relation to a Federal judge with a letter from an aggrieved litigant is, of course, an absurdity.

Everybody knows how seriously the Government is taking these allegations. Everybody knows that if they were vexatious or frivolous allegations the Government, with all the resources available to it, would have demonstrated that beyond argument long before now. But we all know that they are not vexatious allegations, they are not frivolous; they are serious enough for the Attorney- General to take the extraordinary step of twice discussing these allegations with the Federal judge concerned. They are serious enough for him to get two legal opinions. They are serious enough to cause the establishment of a joint Commonwealth-State task force. They are serious enough for material to be sent to Mr Redlich. They are serious enough for material to be sent to the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. They are serious enough for one of the people asked to give an opinion to the Government to warn the judge in question that he had better be careful of whom he associates with in future. That is a fairly unprecedented warning for anybody to give to a Federal judge. When the Minister representing the Attorney-General, the Deputy Prime Minister, replies I invite him to draw on examples of when that sort of thing has occurred before.

We are dealing with no frivolous letter of complaint from an aggrieved litigant . We are dealing with substantive allegations. We are dealing with allegations which need to be probed. We are requiring of the Government that it enable this Parliament to discharge its constitutional responsibility. Until this Parliament is provided with the material that is in the possession of the Government, until this Parliament has an opportunity to find out whether there is other relevant material, how do we know whether there are not other tapes in the possession of other arms of the Government? How do we know whether, on due inquiry, we might not establish the existence of other material? How do we know whether on due inquiry we will not find that other questions, possibly involving misconduct and misbehaviour, may exist?

The simple fact is that while this Parliament is denied access to the material that is now in the hands of the Government, the Executive constantly obstructs the Parliament in the discharge of its constitutional responsibilities. For the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General to say 'I have Temby's opinion', 'I have the Solicitor-General's opinion' or 'I have the Attorney-General's opinion', is to invite us in this Parliament to substitute their judgment for ours. If the founding fathers had wanted the Attorney-General, the Prime Minister or the Solicitor-General to decide such a matter they would have said so but, expressly for the reasons that were so clearly set out by Mr Barton in the convention debates, they made it clear that ultimately that power had to rest with this Parliament. While this Government continues to obstruct, deny and prevent this Parliament from exercising its constitutional responsibilities the concerns out in the community will multiply. Nothing that the Attorney-General has yet said has satisfied the Opposition or, dare I say, the discerning public on this issue .

At this stage I draw no final conclusion about the substance of the allegations contained in those tapes. All I know is that they were sufficiently serious for the Attorney-General to take the steps that he did. All I know is that they were sufficiently serious for the other steps that I have outlined to be taken by the Government. While the Government continues to prevent this Parliament from exercising its constitutional responsibility we have a right, indeed, a duty, to continue to press it and to complain.

During debates on this issue a great deal of heat has been generated and appeal made to emotions. We are not talking about a light matter or about vexatious complaints. As I said earlier, if the Government could demonstrate that they are vexatious it certainly would have done so in its own interest long before now. What we are talking about is that, for the first time in many years, perhaps ever, there are grounds for believing that there may need to be an inquiry into allegations that have been made about a judge of a federal court in this country . The Government's response has been totally inadequate. It has added fuel to the suspicion of many that the Prime Minister, after his return from overseas, got together with the Premier of New South Wales and said: 'Let's get Neville to the polls as quickly as possible'.

The Opposition has offered the Government an avenue for having this matter adjudicated by the Parliament away from the heat of battle of the New South Wales State election. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) today asked the Prime Minister whether he would convene an inquiry of this Parliament which would not sit until after the New South Wales election. In other words, we are prepared to remove the matter from the New South Wales State election. That proposal, made despite the political grounds that we have for suspecting the Government's motives, has been rejected by the Government. We can only reach the conclusion that this Executive, from the Prime Minister down, is hell bent on denying this Parliament the right to discharge its proper constitutional responsibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 223rd report of the Committee, relating to HMAS Tobruk, and seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. This report details the findings of the Committee' s inquiry into the amphibious heavy lift ship-HMAS Tobruk-project of the Department of Defence. The inquiry was commenced following the Auditor-General's critical report on the HMAS Tobruk project in March 1982. Initially, the Committee planned to report on the findings of this inquiry in conjunction with its findings on other references from the Auditor-General's March 1982 report. However, because of the magnitude and the seriousness of the problems associated with the project, the Committee decided to issue a separate report on the matter . Among the issues reported on by the Committee are:

SPEECH.PARA: the excess weight of Tobruk;
The Defence Department's poor quality assurance, and its grossly inadequate on- site representation at the shipyard;
the inoperative davit hoist system for the landing craft of the Tobruk;
several alleged major design faults, including a lack of watertight integrity following damage;
major deficiencies in the Defence Department's overall approach to project management; and

the history of design-related problems with HMAS Tobruk in its air conditioning system, engine control system, deck mounting of forward cranes, excessive vibration, underdesigned auxiliary boilers, dangerous sewerage system and inadequate kit lockers.

The Committee is most concerned about the variety of serious problems that were revealed during the inquiry. The Committee questions the failure of the Department of Defence to rectify technical problems which emerged during the HMAS Tobruk project. The Committee would not have expected the Department to have mismanaged the acquisition of a major piece of equipment. During this inquiry the Committee found that many highly significant events and documents were not readily brought to the attention of the Committee by the Department. Rather, their existence was revealed only after prolonged investigation and probing inquiry by the Committee. The Committee was not satisfied with this aspect of the Department's conduct, for it believed that a committee of the Australian Parliament should be given a full and frank account of all relevant events and documents pertinent to the matter under consideration. It is not a matter of receiving information on a 'need to know' basis. It is for the Committee to decide what material is relevant.

I wish to comment further on two matters raised in this report. Firstly, during the Tobruk inquiry the Committee learnt of the tragic death of Naval Reserve Cabet Kenneth Dax and the critical findings of the subsequent board of inquiry, and the Department's review of the report of that board of inquiry. While the Department is to be congratulated for the thoroughness of the review of the board of inquiry report, it is, at the same time, to be severely censured for the deficiencies and mismanagement reported on by the review. The Committee is concerned at the way the Department handled the Dax family's request for information and compensation following the tragic death of their son, Kenneth. The Committee has carefully considered this issue and concludes that the amount of $3,550 is not an adequate amount to compensate for the death of a 14-year-old naval cadet and the subsequent distress to his family. The Committee recommends that the matter should be looked at again and a more adequate amount determined. Secondly, during the inquiry a question on the watertight integrity of HMAS Tobruk following damage was raised. The Committee heard evidence on this serious matter from a variety of sources at both public and in camera hearings, and carefully considered this allegation. The Committee remains doubtful about the watertight integrity of HMAS Tobruk in certain circumstances.
In this report the Committee makes 33 recommendations for action by the Defence Department. Of these I wish to highlight one:

That rectification of HMAS Tobruk's many serious technical problems should be carried out in advance of the scheduled refit. In the meantime consideration should be given to the operation of the ship to ensure its safety.

The Committee wishes to emphasise that it does not question the concept of, or the need for, a ship such as HMAS Tobruk. Clearly, the existence and operation of a heavy lift ship like HMAS Tobruk is of benefit to the Australian defence forces and the Australian community. Similarly, in reporting on the findings of this inquiry the Committee does not question the role of the Australian shipbuilding industry in defence projects. The Committee emphasises that it does not wish to prejudice shipbuilding in Australia. It recognises the valuable contribution to the Australian economy made by Australian shipbuilding companies and their employees, and welcomes the development of this industry.

The Committee believes that the recommendations of this inquiry will go some way towards improving overall project management and administration in the Department of Defence. However, there remains a need for project management in the Department and its related organisations to be further improved. As honourable members will be aware, the Committee will be undertaking a detailed and comprehensive examination into the Defence Department's overall project management and administration this year. With this in mind the Committee requests that the response to this report be available to the Committee on or before 1 September 1984. I commend the report to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr John Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to regulate the use of the Advance Australia logo. On 13 October 1983 the Government announced its decision to introduce legislation so as to ensure, with effect from that date, that the logo is used only in accordance with the objectives of the Advance Australia campaign. The ultimate aim of that campaign is to stimulate demand for Australian goods and services. Consequently the unauthorised use of the logo and look-alike symbols is of considerable concern to the Government as it directly threatens to undermine the campaign and the financial viability of the Advance Australia company.

Before I mention the main provisions in this Bill I will take a few moments to outline the background to Advance Australia. The Advance Australia campaign was launched in 1979 on the recommendation of the Australian Manufacturing Council, an advisory body to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. From 1979 to 1981, the campaign was managed by the Department of Industry and Commerce through the Project Australia Committee which included senior business executives, trade union officials and the Secretary to the Department to Industry and Commerce.

Because of growth in private sector support and interest, a non-profit, public interest company, Advance Australia, was established in mid-1981 to manage the ongoing campaign. The Project Australia Committee became the board of the new company. In the period 1979 to 1983 the Government provided $5.14m to the campaign. A system of licensing arrangements involving the franchise of the Advance Australia logo was also developed to raise revenue for the campaign. These arrangements proved highly successful with over 700 companies actively participating and over $3m in revenue being raised through licensing since 1979. In 1982-83 $1.75m was raised from the licences. Because of this success, the Government ceased its contribution to the campaign on 30 June 1983 and the Advance Australia company is now a self-funding, private sector project.

The Advance Australia campaign has been remarkably well received by the Australian community, achieving very high levels of public awareness and acceptance. It is estimated that the logo now appears in advertising and marketing activities involving more than $2 billion of Australian products. The challenge now facing the company is to maintain and build upon its success. However its financial viability and ongoing success are under threat because of the unauthorised use of the logo and a variety of look-alike symbols by some Australian and overseas companies. Furthermore the Government believes that the use of the logo and look-alike symbols on imported goods is misleading as consumers may be misled that the goods are manufactured in Australia. The unauthorised use of the logo is thus not only threatening the validity of licences issued by Advance Australia but is damaging the interests of existing licence holders.

I now turn to the major provisions of the Bill. Clauses 6 to 8 vest ownership of the copyright of the logo in the Advance Australia company, make the Advance Australia company owner of the design of the logo and provide for the laws applicable to the ownership of personal property to apply also to ownership of the design of the logo. These provisions will allow the company to seek protection against unauthorised use of the design of the logo directly through the courts without the need for Commonwealth involvement.

Generally speaking, the provisions of clause 11 provide for a prohibition on both the importation of articles bearing the logo and the production or sale in Australia, without licence, of articles which bear the logo. An action for infringement of the ownership of the design can be initiated by either Advance Australia or by a licence holder whose interests have been affected by the infringement. If these rights are infringed the courts may grant damages or a sum equal to the amount gained by the unauthorised use.

Safeguard provisions have been incorporated into the Bill to protect the Commonwealth's interest and investment in the campaign. Clause 10 makes provision for the ownership of the logo to revert to the Commonwealth in the event of the company winding up or the Minister being satisfied that it is no longer in the public interest for the company to own the logo. The Minister is also empowered by clause 17 to give directions to the company in connection with the exercise of its powers in relation to the copyright and design of the logo. The company is also required by clause 18 to provide the Minister with an annual report detailing licences issued, amounts received and the application of those funds.

The Government believes that it has a responsibility to protect the Australian firms which have, in good faith, actively supported the Advance Australia campaign and taken out product licences with the Advance Australia company to use the logo in their advertising and marketing. This legislation is therefore necessary to protect the logo and to ensure that the Advance Australia campaign will continue its success with the company having a sound basis for its future operations. The provisions of this Bill do not have any financial implications. I mentioned earlier that the Commonwealth ceased its financial contribution to the campaign on 30 June 1983. Advance Australia is now a self-funding, private sector project. I commend the Bill to the House.
