TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The main purpose of the Quarantine Amendment Bill is to increase the penalties that may be imposed upon persons convicted of offences against the quarantine laws of Australia. The Bill also makes a number of other amendments to the Quarantine Act 1908 to overcome some operational difficulties experienced with the Act, and to make it more responsive to modern situations. I wish to impress upon honourable members the seriousness with which the Government views breaches of quarantine. It is estimated that an outbreak of foot and mouth disease in Australia would bring to a virtual standstill exports of meat and other commodities of livestock origin, and would cause a drop in rural output of the order of $2,500m in the first year.

The penalties under the Quarantine Act were last increased in 1979 to the present maximum level of $10,000 or five years imprisonment. The rural sector has strongly pressed for further increases and has also complained about the inadequacy of fines imposed by the courts. As a deterrent to potential offenders , and as an inducement to the courts to provide higher penalties, the Bill at clause 27 provides for a substantial increase in penalties, particularly the penal sanctions. For example, the maximum penalty for importing a disease agent contrary to the Act is increased from $10,000 or imprisonment for five years to $50,000 or imprisonment for 10 years, or both, or if the offender is a body corporate, $200,000. Where a quarantine emergency exists, any person who does not comply with a direction given to implement emergency measures taken by the Minister, or who hinders or obstructs such measures, will face a maximum penalty of $100,000 or imprisonment for 10 years, or both. The maximum penalty that currently exists is $10,000 or imprisonment for five years.

I now turn to the other amendments in this Bill and address the more substantial provisions. Clause 5 provides for the appointment of the Director of Quarantine and chief quarantine officers by the Minister, and for the appointment of quarantine officers by the Director of Quarantine, instead of these appointments being made by the Governor-General. As there are about 1,700 quarantine officers throughout Australia this amendment will remove a considerable work load from the Governor-General.

Clause 16 provides for the amendments of section 48 of the Act relating to goods ordered into quarantine. Section 48 provides that where goods ordered into quarantine cannot be effectively treated or disinfected and ought not to be released from quarantine, the goods may be destroyed. The clause amends section 48 to provide a review of the opinion of the quarantine officer immediately in charge of goods where those goods are live animals by vesting the decision to destroy the animals in a chief quarantine officer. The clause also includes a new provision to enable the owner of any goods to be notified where the goods cannot be treated without damaging them, so that the owner can be given an opportunity to agree to the course of action proposed. If the owner has not notified his intentions in relation to the goods within 30 days, the goods will be forfeited to the Commonwealth.

Clause 18 extends the powers of inspection of a quarantine officer under the Act to a vessel that is beyond the territorial sea of Australia and is bound for Australia or the Cocos Islands, to the extent that the vessel is within nine nautical miles of the outer limits of the territorial sea. The Governor-General may proclaim a greater distance than nine nautical miles under the provision. The Government considers it desirable for the jurisdiction of the Quarantine Act to be extended over as much territory to which Australia has a legal right of influence as is possible for effective quarantine control. Recent developments in international law have enabled this extension of the powers of inspection.

Clauses 20 and 21 provide powers of search relating to domestic animals in the Cocos Islands. These powers are presently contained in regulations 14 and 19 of the Quarantine (Cocos Islands) Regulations. They are being included in the Quarantine Act following reservations expressed by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances about the powers of quarantine officers to enter premises in the Cocos Islands, and advice by the Attorney-General's Department that the inclusion of such powers in subordinate legislation was inappropriate. Arrangements are in train for the repeal of the relevant regulations.

Clause 25 provides for the Minister to have the power to determine the levels of fees for quarantine services instead of such fees being prescribed by regulation. Such determinations will be subject to the scrutiny of Parliament as the clause also provides that the determinations will be subject to certain provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. These provisions are for the laying of regulations before both Houses of Parliament, the disallowance of regulations, and the effect of the repeal of regulations. This provision will facilitate the introduction of new fee levels in accordance with the Government' s policy for the recovery of direct operating costs for quarantine services.

Clause 26 of the Bill provides a new regulation making power to put beyond doubt the scope of the act to control the storage, use, movement and disposal of goods, including disease agents where the goods are permitted to be imported by the Minister or the Director of Quarantine for a particular purpose for use in a particular location, such as a research establishment or diagnostic laboratory. The remaining provisions of this Bill make minor amendments of a machinery or procedural nature in order to facilitate the more efficient administration of the Act. There will be no financial impact from any of these provisions. I commend the Bill to the House.

It transfers discrimination from those opposed to the basic standards set down in Australian society today to those who support those standards.
Government members-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously honourable members opposite have not read the Bill. It transfers discrimination from the rights of the accused to the rights of the accusers. That is something which I do not think exists in any other piece of legislation. The attempts of the Opposition today to change that have been unsuccessful, as honourable members opposite well know. That is the type of discrimination which this piece of paper introduces to Australian society. It entrenches the rights of an institution, such as a church. The Government's amendments have agreed to the rights of a church to discriminate on the grounds of marriage, but the Government has refused to give that right to an individual. It refuses the rights to an individual to discriminate even though that person may be a practising member of that church. Let us remember the style of discrimination that people want to practice. For instance, they might say that they would like to lease a house in Canberra, which is next door to the house in which they live and has no fence-this example was raised earlier-to a married couple because they have a deep commitment to marriage. Under this legislation those people will be discriminated against. The minute we pass this legislation those people will be discriminated--
—No, they are not.
—Gerry, you are showing absolute ignorance of this Bill if you do not understand that.
—Order! The honourable member will direct his comments through the Chair. The honourable member for Melbourne will not interject.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker; you are quite right. All this is to be achieved by the creation of a commission. I know of the Government's commitment to resolving unemployment. I know that it will create jobs whenever it can, but now we will be creating a very large number of jobs to achieve something that has been evolving in Australia for many years. I questioned the remarks of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) the other day when he told us of the great improvements women had achieved for themselves, and quite rightly so. I said to him: 'Which legislation achieved that?'. The Minister then started to name some. I thought about that. I tend to agree that there has been some legislation which achieved that. Certainly there has been legislation which has achieved equal pay for women. That legislation was quite positive, but basically it removed the discrimination of paying people different salaries. When one looks at many other pieces of legislative activity one sees that in each case discrimination that existed in legislation was removed. But this Bill is not about removing discrimination that exists in government legislation. It is about imposing discrimination on people who no longer wish or have never wished to accept a particular philosophy expounded by some 70 people in this place. That is the great difference between this legislation and legislative action that has in the past removed legislative discrimination against women and, for that matter, discrimination as far as sex is concerned.
—Time.

—When I hear someone say 'time' I usually gather that that person does not like hearing what I have to say because it is embarrassing to that person. Another matter I want to refer to in my speech is the regular occurrence of speakers on both sides of the House telling us how discriminated against women must be. They cite figures and tell us, for instance, that there are only so many women in this place, in a particular work force, et cetera. I have a favourite statistic that I like to cite when people start running their statistics. It is a statistical fact that lions have killed more Western Australians than sharks have. But I can inform honourable members that when I go swimming I take a lot more care than I do when I go bushwalking. Quite clearly, statistics prove nothing, as that statistic does not. It is quite ridiculous, but it is an absolute fact. The honourable member for Canning (Ms Fatin) would know why. They used to climb the fence into the zoo in South Perth.
—Women?

—No, people wishing to commit suicide. The fact that I am trying to put to honourable members is that statistics are grossly ridiculous. They are ridiculous to use in the context of this debate. There are numerous reasons why women do not have the same numbers as men in the work force. Some of the reasons are probably unfortunate and wrong. One reason that women do not enter the work force in the same numbers as men is that they do not always choose to do so. This Government should be about the right to choose.
—It is.

—We will see about that. We will see about the right to choose. There is a lady sitting in this place-I believe she is still sitting behind me-whose photograph appears in a newspaper above an article which states what will happen to us immediately this Bill is passed. The article appears under the heading ' Enforce affirmative action: Green Paper'. This lady might go back to the other place shortly and deny all this, but I would say that the leak probably came from her office; it is too detailed. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Companies should be legally bound to implement affirmative action programs for women employees and report annually to an affirmative action commissioner,-
There is to be another one of them which means even more jobs for the boys. The article continues:
says a discussion paper prepared by the Federal Government.

That article appeared at page 9 in the Melbourne Age of 2 March l984. There has been plenty of time to deny it. We have been told in relation to this Bill that we will not have affirmative action. Affirmative action is a fine term, but I do not know who will define it. Certainly it is not defined in this Bill. I gather that affirmative action could probably be described as putting your money where your mouth is; in other words, following your own principles. I believe that is a message to all the civil servants currently employed in Australia by at least the Commonwealth Government, which has put this legislation in place and is proposing, therefore, to have its affirmative action follow the principles laid down in its legislation and consequently--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the honourable member to stick to the subject matter of this legislation.

—I would have thought that on this Bill, and with the discussion on affirmative action that has occurred to date, it is very relevant, and I ask to be able to complete my few words in this regard. The point I wish to raise again on this is, of course, discrimination.

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. On the ruling that you just made that the honourable member should return to the Bill, he has debated your ruling and then proceeded on his merry way. I think you should stick to your ruling and make him stick to the Bill.
—There is no point of order but I ask the honourable member for O'Connor to take note of my comments.
—I will stick to the Bill but I again raise the point that there has been considerable discussion of affirmative action in the debates to date. That is as far as I have gone.
—I hope you do not start to debate the ruling of the Chair.

—I will take your ruling to stick to the Bill, Mr Deputy Speaker, although I do not believe I have transgressed that ruling. This Bill states that the only way that discrimination cannot apply is to apply quotas to the employment of the sexes in, say, the civil service-I give that as an example. I ask honourable members to think of the discrimination that might occur when we find in the work force a distortion that is created suddenly, or even over a period--

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The remarks that the honourable member for O'Connor is making are certainly nothing to do with the Bill. He is trying to get round your ruling. I suggest that he come back to the Bill.
—I take the point of order and I ask the honourable member for O'Connor to remain relevant to the Bill.

—I accept your point, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is quite clear that the Government is imposing in this Bill-I refer to the Bill and nothing else-a massive sham on the Australian people and this Parliament. The Government has denied time and again that there will be any move to affirmative action. What is it doing? It is too embarrassed even to let me raise some examples of the consequences of that. It is a shame. It is deliberate. The Government will go ahead with it and the quicker the Australian public knows of another one of its tricks, the better. There would be no other reason to stop me. I have a few minutes left and that is my entitlement. The honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) is happy to let me talk on anything but affirmative action. That is absolute proof of the Government's intention. The Australian work force and the civil service will soon see men having to stay at home because the only member of the family who can get a job will be the wife, which may not be her choice.
—Ha, ha!

—The honourable member for Canning should not laugh about it. That is her intention. She would be thrilled to bits to see that. I do not care if within that family that is its own decision. I am suggesting that in many cases it may not be the decision. More than anything, I am saying that the Government has misled the Parliament today in all its statements saying that it would not do it. That was adequately proved by the honourable member for McMillan trying to interrupt my speech in that regard. He was not in the least bit concerned about anything else.

SPEECH.PARA: What will be the result of this? As is usual with this type of legislation, as with many other pieces of legislation, the public will learn. It will learn not to advertise this and not to advertise that. The Commissioner has no hope, for instance, of getting into the 700,000 small businesses in this country which employ fewer than 10 people to find out what they are doing behind his back. The Government has made a law that it cannot police. It will be abused by a few and the rest will go on their merry way. They will not advertise their preferences any more. That is what the Government has delivered. It has delivered another inquisition. It will be like the 1,400 inquisitors it has put in to chase pensioners. Now it will have another mob of inquisitors to chase small business people. I can tell the Government that it will be rejected by them. We will have a highly paid Commissioner sitting down listening to a few of these things. The other day, in thinking about the field of sexual harassment, I wondered how a female member of this place will feel in future under this legislation when she hears the Speaker say: 'Close the doors'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not understand that.

—The honourable member would not understand it. He is not quick enough . But it is not a bad joke. I hope some of my comments are realised. I am against the Bill-not the concept of anything that it attempts to do. It fails to do it miserably.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My support of the Sex Discrimination Bill has not been dependent upon the acceptance of the amendments and, therefore, I am pleased to speak briefly at the third reading in support of it. I do so knowing that my State has been a pioneer in matters of anti-discrimination legislation. I pay tribute to a former Premier of South Australia, Mr David Tonkin, who when he was in opposition in 1975 saw his earlier moves come to fruition when a Bill was passed through the South Australian Parliament on this matter. In addition to that, the South Australian division of the Liberal Party of Australia is keenly aware of this issue and the women's council of that division is very much in support of this type of legislation. I am pleased to support it personally and on the basis of my State and my Party's involvement in the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a State parliamentary colleague, the honourable member for Coles, Mrs Adamson, who has put an interesting slant on this issue in the addresses that she has given on the matter. She takes the hypothetical view of what would happen in the community if parliaments were dominated by women instead of men. Of course, here we have a parliament almost totally dominated by men, with some notable exceptions to whom the Australian Labor Party is very proud to refer. Of course, it is justified in its pride in the sense that it has more women in the Parliament than we do. In her addresses Mrs Adamson goes through a list of what would be different in the community if parliaments were indeed composed of a majority of women. Without knowing all the points she makes, it is interesting to run through some that are similar. She points out that, of course, financial institutions would have no bias in favour of men. There would be far more child minding centres in the community. The tax system would be adjusted to take out inequalities and no doubt there would be some form of tax splitting in single income families. She points out that hours of work would be staggered to allow women to work more flexible hours to suit their family obligations. There would be a much better retention rate in education because much closer attention would be given to children's needs. There would be more kindergartens. There would be less procrastination and delay in the administration of family law and there would be a greater emphasis on sex education. Those are just a few things that one can list that would be different in this community if we had parliaments dominated by women. I believe that is a very proper way to approach this issue.

The scene as I see it in relation to this legislation is to encourage an attitude of mind. I do not expect there to be punitive hunts, that people will be hunted down or prosecuted to any degree. The movement around Australia in this form of legislation is to encourage a different frame of mind and it will be a long process. Nothing will happen next year to any great degree that did not happen this year. It will be a long process of encouragement. As the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) has said, it will be governed by political acceptance of this in the community. If any government were to seize this legislation and administer it in a heavy handed fashion it would lose political support. It would be a very direct equation; it would be very quickly translated into a loss of voting support. The Government would be changed possibly on that issue alone, and we would have the legislation amended. Of course, as one who supports the legislation now, I say quite freely that if it does not work or if something needs to be changed in it, I would be the first to support amendments to remedy the difficulties that may arise. I am sure that those who originated the legislation would see it as being somewhat experimental and would themselves be prepared to look at amendments as soon as they are required.

It is a sobering thought, of course, that exemptions are given on religious grounds. I do not want to develop that thought further, but it is a sobering and disappointing thought that the provisions have been put into this legislation. I support these provisions because I can see no way of not putting them in with the community as we have it, but I am disappointed that it is on religious grounds that some discrimination is allowed. I believe the legislation is an example to the rest of the world. I do not say that with any sort of overwhelming sense of the importance of Australia to the rest of the world, but we have to give a lead, along with other nations which adopt this sort of legislation. Discrimination on grounds of sex and race are of very great dimension in many sections of the world. Such discrimination will go on for a long time into the future. Examples need to be given from what, it is to be hoped, are the more developed communities so that changes can be encouraged in the more backward ones. I believe that is something that has not been largely emphasised in the debate on this legislation, but for me it is one of the most important aspects to be considered in accepting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why the Convention is so important.

—Of course, as my colleague says, that is why the Convention is so important. Thus I support the legislation, not because it will do all the intricate things that some who are concerned about it think it will do, but simply because it will encourage equality in this community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is disappointed that the amendments to the Sex Discrimination Bill which we proposed were rejected. The Bill is, however, as has been observed, a considerable improvement on the original. We fully expect that when the Bill is actually implemented the Government will need to rectify some of the defects and other blemishes to which we have pointed. In spite of that disappointment, I intend to vote for the Bill as I believe it is legislation of a very important character. Some people who have been opposed to the Bill in the general public debate have said that the legislation demeans the status of women who choose not to enter the paid work force. The Bill removes barriers which demean the status of women who seek to enter the paid work force. It may be that some married women feel less secure than they would like because of a desire of some others to have both a career and their own family life. Opposition to this Bill obviously will not alleviate that insecurity.

SPEECH.PARA: It has also been asserted by some that the Bill will encourage the breakdown of the family unit by enticing more women into the work force. Of course, it does not entice them but merely seeks to remove barriers to women who feel obliged by economic circumstances or who wish to enter the paid work force. Nothing in this Bill or indeed any other Bill as such can encourage or prevent the breakdown of a marriage. Other policies of government outside the range of this Bill can help to alleviate strains that often cause the destruction of marriages.

It has been said that the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women has made Australia subject to external interference in our domestic law. The fact is that provisions which were complained of are similar to those which are in other international instruments to which we have subscribed. In practice, there will not be, as there has not been in other areas, interference in our domestic laws by any external organisation or other country.

It is often said that supporters of this Bill are young feminist activists who are against the traditional role of wife and mother. The truth is, of course, that ordinary Australian men and women support this legislation. They believe that discrimination is wrong and that we ought to enable people, not oblige them , to exercise individual choice. They believe also that individual and family life may be enriched by enabling men and women to share responsibilities at home and in the paid work force. Of course, people, including me, sometimes get a bit militant when the progress is slower than it ought to be. Many people feel ill at ease in a world in which there have been rapid changes of attitude. That, I think, underlies some of the opposition to legislation of this character.

Indirect discrimination has been one of the areas exposed by State legislation that have been most disturbing. Those areas of indirect discrimination have been dealt with by this legislation. They underlie some of the greater concerns that are now being expressed. Thus, it is one thing to remove, for example, the ban on married women being permanent public servants; that is, a ban that most of us recall being in existence not very many years ago. It is quite another thing to remove from the promotion criteria an emphasis upon length of service. If a major criterion for promotion is seniority or length of service, by definition, a woman who has left the Service temporarily to bear and rear children faces a barrier compared with men or women who have remained in the Service uninterrupted. Thus the designers of job and management generally have the task of examining the repercussions of this less direct but very real discrimination which women suffer. That is the next step in the education process.

Similarly, there are presumed capacities to do so-called heavy work, to which the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) referred. I would have thought that the farmer who wanted a strong person would actually advertise for a strong person. In fact, nine times out of ten, it might be a male.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just advertise for a man.

—No, the honourable member for O'Connor is quite wrong. There are plenty of case studies to testify to this. For example, Esso has published material about its experiences at Sale where it was assumed that any male who applied for jobs with certain specifications, would get the job if healthy. Jobs which involved going up ladders, lifting heavy lids off cylinders and putting gauges into the cylinders had to be occupied by a male. In fact, when Esso decided to open the job to females, the males helped design the job specifications which set out certain strength requirements. They were then amazed at the number of males who failed the test and the number of females who passed it.
—What about league football?

—I hear mention of league football. The New South Wales Rugby League is now admitting females as referees. I will not reduce the debate to an absurdity about sports which people choose to play on the basis of sex. It is important that in the way in which people earn their living no one should presume certain characteristics on the basis of sex.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, there are other areas of discrimination which I do not believe I need to go into, with the exception of the job interview situation. As is frequently said, at a job interview a woman is asked whether she plans to start a family. She may be asked various indirect questions aimed at ascertaining an answer to that question on the basis that people want to know how long she will stay in the job. Men are not asked that question, because they cannot become pregnant. They are not asked a question about whether they might be attracted to employment elsewhere by an increased wage offer. It is questioning the assumptions of people that is so important. If at the end of the day the only common sense is that a person of a particular sex should be employed, that will be the situation.

The reason progress has been made in this field is not due to the absence of legislation but to the existence of legislation in three States. That has helped the public debate greatly. This legislation will help the public debate still further. I just hope that 20 years from now our children, especially female children, will not find in their way in the areas covered by this legislation the barriers which have been there for the last 20 years. One just hopes that this will be one more step in the education process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I want to thank all honourable members for their participation. This has been a rather extensive third reading debate. The purpose of the third reading debate is to indicate basically that one either agrees or disagrees with the Bill. I note that there have been some comments that the Sex Discrimination Bill is not altogether what some honourable members would like it to be. I want to congratulate the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) for his approach to this legislation. It has been basically one of support. I think it is very important in the Australian context that in matters of this nature the people of Australia see some consensus in our attempts to make a strong democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make it very clear that on 18 December 1979-I think this is of some significance-the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women was adopted. I note that the Australian women who were at that Convention participated in the drafting of the text. Australia was amongst the early signatories of that Convention at the initial stage. In fairness to the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) I suggest that he misunderstands the position of sex and discrimination. I think that is basically it. The only problem with his argument is that if it is a question of ability-he keeps making that point-there is nothing wrong with the Bill. One cannot discriminate against ability but one can discriminate against sex. The honourable member seems to be getting confused. I know that no matter how long we tried to argue the matter here we would never get the Bill through to the honourable gentleman.

The other point that the honourable member raised had some thrust, in the sense that he felt there would be some affirmative action campaign because a newspaper article had said so. I am reminded that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the second reading debate gave a very firm assurance that the article was without any foundation.
Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Public opinion will always be reminded of our promises and accordingly we expect to remain here for a long while. Honourable members opposite must not get too carried away with what I have just said. The point is that the Prime Minister said in the second reading debate that he totally rejected that newspaper report. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government has no intention of imposing anything on the private sector that is unrealistic or unworkable. It would be utterly counter-productive to do so.

I make that point and ask honourable members opposite not to get too carried away with the politics of it. We on the Government side want to congratulate the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Ryan) for her efforts in bringing this legislation forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was her newspaper article.

—I am talking about positive matters. We now have a Bill which is a tangible ratification of the Convention, and it is worth while looking at. We are very much aware of the pressures, the strain and the obligations that come upon a Minister having the carriage of such a Bill, and our congratulations go to our Minister for her excellent work in that regard. I also congratulate the women members of the Australian Labor Party for their support.
—Stop grovelling.

—I do not need to. I am in an office where I do not need to. I think it is very important that in today's democracy in Australia we get participation of all the women in our community. It has not happened in the past . Many of us have come up through life knowing full well the problems that have bedevilled the female members of our families. Many a child has been disadvantaged because of the inability of the mother to get equal opportunity as a result of discrimination against sex. I wish to make a point which is very appropriate. The Schedule to the Convention states that the parties to the Convention are:

SPEECH.PARA: Concerned that in situations of poverty women have the least access to food, health, education, training and opportunities for employment and other needs.

That has been a sad indictment on all countries, not just Australia, which would be so much stronger and so much better equipped to look after its people and the nation if women were given their appropriate role and equal rights and opportunities. That is all it means. The more education we can give to the women in our society, the better the society is. The more opportunities they get, the stronger the society is. The Schedule to the Convention makes another thrust which reads as follows:
Convinced that the full and complete development of a country, the welfare of the world and the cause of peace require the maximum participation of women on equal terms with men in all fields.
If we can get to that, we will have a better world.
Question put.
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Proceedings (Excess of Jurisdiction) Bill 1984 is dry stuff indeed by comparison with the kind of debate we had on the previous Bill. However, I suppose commerce must be served as well as equality and that is what we are going to do now. The Opposition supports this Bill. The purposes of the Bill, stated briefly, are to consolidate and refine existing legislation which was passed by the previous Government which protects Australian laws, policies and interests against the extraterritorial application of foreign laws and to provide certain further measures, essentially, as I understand it, measures which had been considered by the previous Government as well. The purpose of the legislation is to ensure that Australia will have available a comprehensive arsenal of defences, to use the words in the explanatory memorandum, if faced with a challenge to what is described as its sovereignty or national interest by the extraterritorial application of foreign laws. Of course, the legislation is most particularly concerned with the extraterritorial application of United States of America anti-trust laws.

SPEECH.PARA: In general terms the Bill empowers the Attorney-General to make orders or instruments having a variety of effects, which are essentially orders prohibiting the production of evidence for the purposes of a foreign tribunal- that is to say, in cases where the Attorney-General for the reasons which are permitted of him, orders that that should not be done-and to the making of an instrument blocking foreign anti-trust judgments. As well, an Australian defendant will be able to recover back either a proportion of or all money awarded in foreign anti-trust proceedings where the Attorney-General has made an appropriate order. The Attorney-General will also be able to make orders blocking other actions or decisions of foreign governments under laws relating to trade or commerce imposing an obligation upon an Australian person or company that has to be performed in Australia. He will also be able to make an order blocking judgments of a foreign court that would require or prohibit an act being done in Australia or would require a person to refrain from conduct in Australia.

The reason for this legislation is essentially the very long reach of the United States anti-trust laws. In this respect two examples can be given from recent times. The first one is the Westinghouse case. The second, which I understand in fact came to nothing, is a case which was commenced in the United States courts. That case had the purpose of preventing mining operations in Western Australia that were contrary to the views put forward by the plaintiff in the American court. The Westinghouse case is the best known to Australians. Honourable members may recall that the Westinghouse Corporation took action against a number of companies, including foreign companies, in relation to certain marketing procedures involving uranium. Very high amounts were claimed by way of damages. Some of the foreign companies refused to enter an appearance in the American jurisdiction. Because of the consequences, the Australian Government took action and the Foreign Anti-trust Judgments (Restriction of Enforcement) Act 1979 was passed. However, in the end there was a settlement agreement which was worked out in 1980 with some of the defendants. The four Australian defendants settled for a sum of $US11,270,000. That action related, as I understand it, to events outside the United States but which were judged or alleged to result in American interests, in this case the interests of Westinghouse, being affected.

The other case to which I referred very briefly and which I will refer to now at slightly more length was the case brought by an organisation called the Conservation Council of Western Australia Incorporated. The case was brought in the United States District Court and the defendants were the Aluminium Company of America and Reynolds Metals. A variety of orders were sought in the United States District Court on behalf of, so it was alleged, some or all of the residents of Western Australia. It is just a little bizarre to think that such an action was brought in a United States court. The relief that was sought was, amongst other things, declaring the rights of the people of Western Australia in relation to mining and seeking certain injunctive relief. One would have thought it was perfectly preposterous that such an action should be allowed to proceed. I believe-I am not certain of this-that the action was eventually dismissed as being ill-founded. I have not seen the records so I cannot verify that. Certainly it is an example of an attempt to reach out into other jurisdictions. The view that has been taken by the previous Government and which is taken by this Government is that it is necessary to have protection against the reach of American courts.

It is perfectly true that an agreement has been worked out between the Australian Government and the American Government which, as is pointed out in the second reading speech of the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen), sets up a framework for consultation and co-operation. One of the problems is that the best the American Government can ever do when it seeks to come to the assistance , at the request of the Australian Government, of Australian companies who find themselves defendants in American courts in respect of actions which are taking place entirely outside America is for the American Government to seek to persuade the court to come to a certain result. It is therefore in no better position than any other litigant. The Government takes the view, and I think it is a sensible view, that we need to have available to us protections of a legal kind which can be put into effect.

It is pointed out in the second reading speech that one of the problems that is faced by foreign companies is that they may have become involved in speculative actions commenced in American courts. I hope that those who think speculative actions are a good thing might recall this in the future. It is in effect an invitation to lawyers to get together, find themselves clients and start some proceedings because if one sues enough big companies one just might get them coming to the table to make very large settlements rather than face continuing legal actions. Of course, the United States Government cannot control those sorts of actions. Again, that is why we need to have some legal means of preventing those actions having an effect on Australian companies when it would be contrary to the national interest and when it would be contrary to the rules of international law or international comity, although what those exceedingly vague expressions mean is another matter. The Deputy Prime Minister, in his second reading speech, said:
There has been no significant change in US domestic anti-trust laws to take account of foreign government interests and no modification of their wide jurisdictional claims.

Recalling that seeking to cut down the reach of these courts would be a very low priority on the part of the Administration and that the wide reach of United States anti-trust courts would have the general support, one would think, of many congressmen and certainly many American companies, the chances are fairly bleak that we will see any substantial modification of the avowed reach of American courts. That is a further reason why something needs to be done in terms of legislation.

The Bill which is before the House, as with the other legislation, is radical in concept because in the case of judgments regularly procured in countries with sophisticated legal systems, such as the United States and Australia, the general rule is that if a judgment has been obtained regularly in one country it should be available to be enforced in other countries. Here we are saying that there are judgments which, for a variety of reasons, should not be enforced. There are various other steps in legal proceedings which, for a variety of reasons, we need to be in a position to stop their having an effect on Australian companies or citizens. The reason is, of course, the national interest. It is perhaps ironic that we are here seeking to limit the jurisdiction of American courts and one of these days we may find ourselves in a position of seeking to clothe Australian courts with the same long reach that American courts now have. If we do that we will be seeking to clothe Australian courts with that long reach on the grounds of national interest. But in this case the American view of national interest and the Australian view of its national interest may, as the Bill illustrates and as history illustrates, come into collision. We must, of course, make a decision which accords with our national interests.

In another place Senator Durack expressed some concern about the width of some of the powers under the Bill. I well understand his concern. I do, however, observe that provision is made for parliamentary oversight of any orders or instruments which the Attorney-General may make under the Bill when it becomes an Act. Those orders or instruments are to be treated as regulations made under the relevant provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act and hence are open to this Parliament's scrutiny. This House can, if it wishes, in accordance with the provisions of sections 48, 49, 49A and 50-so far as they may apply-disallow orders or instruments by the Attorney-General made under this Bill when it becomes an Act.

Therefore in summary we support the legislation and hope that in future we will be able to work out whatever problems we may experience by means of consultation with the American Government rather than having to exercise the powers under the Act when this legislation becomes an Act. But we must face up to the fact that neither the American Government nor the Australian Government can control what litigants may seek to do in the American legal system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wells Mr D.McM.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure, in supporting the Foreign Proceedings (Excess of Jurisdiction) Bill, to speak after the Parliament's most distinguished Queen's Counsel, although correspondingly the learned silk opposite might find himself with a junior he would hardly have chosen himself.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I would like to go further and explain, in language that I think the layman and laywoman would understand, what this Bill is about. The Bill is designed to meet a challenge to the sovereignty of Australia by the extraterritorial application of foreign laws, which means it is designed to meet an attempt by foreign law making bodies and judicial bodies to impose laws having application in Australia. An Australian person, party or a company which is incorporated in Australia might do something which is entirely legal in Australia but which contravenes a foreign law which is expressed as having application in Australia. Now if that foreign law expressed as having application in Australia is then taken to court by a person in a foreign jurisdiction, the Australian people or the company might find themselves at the mercy of foreign laws. There is a problem of justice when such things happen because people are entitled to order their affairs in such a way that they do not breach the laws of the country in which they are operating and, consequently , they should not be liable to the capricious advent of foreign restrictions.

There is no problem at the moment as regards the foreign application of laws in Australia and this is a very good reason for acting now. If we were to introduce legislation such as this when some case came up, such as the Westinghouse case which was referred to by the honourable and learned member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) a moment ago, we would be seen as acting in response to that and our action would exacerbate the international tension which would already exist with the case going on. There is not at the moment before Australian courts or Australian litigants any case of a foreign company or a foreign law attempting to restrict the activities of people acting within the rights which they have in Australia. This is a good reason for bringing down this legislation at this moment because we will not be adding to any antagonism that would otherwise exist.

The most recent incident illustrating the necessity for legislation of this type was, as the honourable member for North Sydney mentioned, the Westinghouse case. That sort of case will not occur again once this legislation is passed. The Attorney-General will have several powers under this legislation. First of all, he will be able to prohibit the production of evidence that could be used for the purposes of a foreign court. Then he will be able to make a legal instrument which will block the effect of foreign anti-trust judgments. He will be able to prevent foreign governments in the area of trade or commerce imposing an obligation on an Australian company or person that has to be performed in Australia. If a foreign court makes a judgment that will force someone to do something or prevent someone from doing something in Australia, the Attorney- General can block it.

This Bill will put Australia's relations with its trading partners on a clear basis-namely we will preserve our sovereignty and trade and deal with those people as equals in the sense that we will not attempt to do the same to them at this stage. Consequently, this announcement of Australia's insistence upon its integrity is welcome at this time. I applaud the Opposition for its support for this Bill and I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. I understand that TAA did not receive approval from the previous Government to the form of accounts until March 1983, which prevented finalisation of the accounts prior to 26 April 1983.

It has adopted this approach for a period of 25 years. (13) See answer to question 4.

(14) TAA adopted a number of cost cutting measures during 1981-82 and 1982-83. TAA has advised that the major items were a large reduction in staff numbers through voluntary retrenchment and early retirement programs, the application of strict control on aircraft scheduling, and an almost total freeze expenditure commencements. Other diverse measures flowing from a total review of expenditure levels included the elimination of coach transport and city check-in, the centralisation of certain administrative functions, an energy management program , and further improvements in control of funds management.
TAA has advised that, due to these programs, costs are now running at some $42m below levels that would otherwise have been the case.
(15) See answer to (14) above.

(16) (a) and (b) It is incorrect to state that it was this Government's decision to inject $115m capital funds into TAA. The previous Government made an interim capital injection of $25m in December 1982, and was to review the position by March 1983.

The information available to this Government indicated that TAA was seriously under capitalised and had been for a number of years. Despite having consistently produced profitable results, TAA had not been allowed use of the profits for expansion and purchase of new capital equipment. This had forced TAA to borrow heavily.

Prior to taking a decision on additional capital, the Government was provided with forecasts of both future cash flow and future profitability by TAA. The details of these forecasts are commercially confidential to TAA.

The Government provided a further capital injection in May 1983 to $90m. The capital injection was to place TAA on a more sound commercial footing. The Government realised that TAA could not be expected to operate on a normal commercial basis with inadequate capital funding.

(c) The additional capital funding of $90m provided by this Government was used by TAA primarily to restructure its debt and allow borrowings to be reduced. It was an essential measure designed to make the airline more competitive, to reduce costs and help keep air fares down.

(d) The ANA Act provides that the Commission shall pay to the Commonwealth, out of the profits of the Commission for a financial year, such amount as the Minister with the concurrence of the Minister for Finance determines. Given the uncertainties about level of future profits, and the currently depressed state of the domestic aviation market, it would not be appropriate to estimate future dividends.

(17) The capital injected, together with self help measures taken by TAA, has allowed TAA to contain cost increases, and minimise air fare increases. Currently the domestic aviation industry is rather depressed, which limits the scope for new initiatives. Nevertheless, TAA, together with Ansett, introduced 45 per cent discount fares, subject to certain conditions aimed at preventing revenue dilution, on many routes in June last year.
